{"uri": "2024-06-388492137", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-13", "time": "14:20:42", "dateTime": "2024-06-13T14:20:42Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-13T13:40:50Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.929411768913269, "url": "https://www.register-herald.com/news/nation_world/us-reporter-evan-gershkovich-jailed-in-russia-on-espionage-charges-to-stand-trial-officials-say/article_980101af-30a2-5b34-98a6-d246442923c5.html", "title": "US reporter Evan Gershkovich, jailed in Russia on espionage charges, to stand trial, officials say", "body": "FILE - Wall Street Journal reporter Evan Gershkovich stands in a glass cage in a courtroom at the First Appeals Court of General Jurisdiction in Moscow, Russia, April 23, 2024. Gershkovich, who has been jailed for over a year in Russia on espionage charges, will stand trial in the city of Yekaterinburg, authorities said Thursday June 13, 2024.\n\nMOSCOW (AP) -- U.S. journalist Evan Gershkovich, who has been jailed for over a year in Russia on espionage charges, will stand trial in the Ural Mountains city of Yekaterinburg, authorities said Thursday.\n\nAn indictment of the Wall Street Journal reporter has been finalized and his case was filed to the Sverdlovsky Regional Court in the city about 1,400 kilometers (870 miles) east of Moscow, according to Russia's Prosecutor General's office.\n\nGershkovich is accused of \"gathering secret information\" for the CIA about Uralvagonzavod, a facility in the Sverdlovsk region that produces and repairs military equipment, the Prosecutor General's office said in a statement, revealing for the first time the details of the accusations against him.\n\nThe officials didn't provide any evidence to back up the accusations. There was no word on when the trial would begin.\n\nGershkovich was detained while on a reporting trip to Yekaterinburg in March 2023 and accused of spying for the United States. The reporter, his employer and the U.S. government denied the allegations, and Washington designated him as wrongfully detained.\n\nThe Federal Security Service, or FSB, alleged at the time he was acting on U.S. orders to collect state secrets but also provided no evidence.\n\nPresident Vladimir Putin has said he believed a deal could be reached to free Gershkovich, hinting he would be open to swapping him for a Russian national imprisoned in Germany, which appeared to be Vadim Krasikov. He was serving a life sentence for the 2019 killing in Berlin of a Georgian citizen of Chechen descent.\n\nAsked last week by The Associated Press about Gershkovich, Putin said the U.S. is \"taking energetic steps\" to secure his release. He said any such releases \"aren't decided via mass media\" but through a \"discreet, calm and professional approach.\"\n\n\"And they certainly should be decided only on the basis of reciprocity,\" he added in an allusion to a potential prisoner swap.\n\nGershkovich faces up to 20 years in prison if convicted.\n\nHe was the first U.S. journalist taken into custody on espionage charges since Nicholas Daniloff in 1986 at the height of the Cold War. Gershkovich's arrest shocked foreign journalists in Russia, even though the country had enacted increasingly repressive laws on freedom of speech after sending troops into Ukraine.\n\nThe son of Soviet emigres who settled in New Jersey, Gershkovich was fluent in Russian and moved to the country in 2017 to work for The Moscow Times newspaper before being hired by the Journal in 2022.\n\nSince his arrest, Gershkovich has been held at Moscow's Lefortovo Prison, a notorious czarist-era prison used during Josef Stalin's purges, when executions were carried out in its basement.\n\nThe Biden administration has sought to negotiate his release, but Russia's Foreign Ministry said it would consider a prisoner swap only after a verdict in his trial.\n\nU.S. Ambassador Lynne Tracy, who regularly visited Gershkovich in prison and attended his court hearings, has called the charges against him \"fiction\" and said that Russia is \"using American citizens as pawns to achieve political ends.\"\n\nSince sending troops to Ukraine, Russian authorities have detained several U.S. nationals and other Westerners, seemingly bolstering that idea.", "source": {"uri": "register-herald.com", Gershkovich has been charged with espionage.\n\nThe officials didn't provide any evidence to back up the accusations.\n\nGershkovich was detained while on a reporting trip to Yekaterinburg in March 2023 and accused of spying for the U.S. The Federal Security Service, or FSB, alleged at the time he was acting on U.S. orders to collect state secrets but also provided no evidence. Washington designated him as wrongfully detained.\n\nHe was the first U.S. journalist taken into custody on espionage charges since Nicholas Daniloff in 1986 at the height of the Cold War. Gershkovich's arrest shocked foreign journalists in Russia, even though the country had enacted increasingly repressive laws on freedom of speech after sending troops into Ukraine.\n\n(Copyright (c) 2024 The Associated Press. {"uri": "2024-06-388536240", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-13", "time": "15:01:26", "dateTime": "2024-06-13T15:01:26Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-13T13:15:19Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8980392217636108, "url": "https://tribtown.com/2024/06/13/us-reporter-evan-gershkovich-jailed-in-russia-on-espionage-charges-to-stand-trial-officials-say/", "title": "US reporter Evan Gershkovich, jailed in Russia on espionage charges, to stand trial, officials say", "body": "FILE - Wall Street Journal reporter Evan Gershkovich stands in a glass cage in a courtroom at the First Appeals Court of General Jurisdiction in Moscow, Russia, April 23, 2024. Gershkovich, who has been jailed for over a year in Russia on espionage charges, will stand trial in the city of Yekaterinburg, authorities said Thursday [...]\n\nMOSCOW (AP) -- U.S. journalist Evan Gershkovich, who has been jailed for over a year in Russia on espionage charges, will stand trial in the Ural Mountains city of Yekaterinburg, authorities said Thursday.\n\nAn indictment of the Wall Street Journal reporter has been finalized and his case was filed to the Sverdlovsky Regional Court in the city about 1,400 kilometers (870 miles) east of Moscow, according to Russia's Prosecutor General's office.\n\nGershkovich is accused of \"gathering secret information\" on orders from the CIA about Uralvagonzavod, a facility in the Sverdlovsk region that produces and repairs military equipment, the Prosecutor General's office said in a statement, revealing for the first time the details of the accusations against him.\n\nThe officials didn't provide any evidence to back up the accusations. There was no word on when the trial would begin.\n\nThe Biden administration has sought to negotiate his release, but Russia's Foreign Ministry said it would consider a prisoner swap only after a verdict in his trial.\n\nGershkovich was detained while on a reporting trip to Yekaterinburg in March 2023 and accused of spying for the United States. The reporter, his employer and the U.S. government denied the allegations, and Washington designated him as wrongfully detained.\n\nThe Federal Security Service, or FSB, alleged at the time he was acting on U.S. orders to collect state secrets but also provided no evidence.\n\nUralvagonzavod, a state tank and railroad car factory in the city of Nizhny Tagil about 100 kilometers (60 miles) north of Yekaterinburg, became known in 2011-12 as a bedrock of support for President Vladimir Putin.\n\nPlant foreman Igor Kholmanskih appeared on Putin's annual phone-in program in December 2011 and denounced mass protests occurring in Moscow at the time as a threat to \"stability,\" proposing that he and his colleagues travel to the capital to help suppress the unrest. A week later, Putin appointed Kholmanskikh to be his envoy in the region.\n\nPutin has said he believed a deal could be reached to free Gershkovich, hinting he would be open to swapping him for a Russian national imprisoned in Germany, which appeared to be Vadim Krasikov. He was serving a life sentence for the 2019 killing in Berlin of a Georgian citizen of Chechen descent.\n\nAsked last week by The Associated Press about Gershkovich, Putin said the U.S. is \"taking energetic steps\" to secure his release. He told international news agencies in St. Petersburg that any such releases \"aren't decided via mass media\" but through a \"discreet, calm and professional approach.\"\n\n\"And they certainly should be decided only on the basis of reciprocity,\" he added in an allusion to a potential prisoner swap.\n\nGershkovich faces up to 20 years in prison if convicted.\n\nHe was the first U.S. journalist taken into custody on espionage charges since Nicholas Daniloff in 1986 at the height of the Cold War. Gershkovich's arrest shocked foreign journalists in Russia, even though the country had enacted increasingly repressive laws on freedom of speech after sending troops into Ukraine.\n\nThe son of Soviet emigres who settled in New Jersey, Gershkovich was fluent in Russian and moved to the country in 2017 to work for The Moscow Times newspaper before being hired by the Journal in 2022.\n\nSince his arrest, Gershkovich has been held at Moscow's Lefortovo Prison, a notorious czarist-era prison used during Josef Stalin's purges, when executions were carried out in its basement.\n\nU.S. Ambassador Lynne Tracy, who regularly visited Gershkovich in prison and attended his court hearings, has called the charges against him \"fiction\" and said that Russia is \"using American citizens as pawns to achieve political ends.\"\n\nSince sending troops to Ukraine, Russian authorities have detained several U.S. nationals and other Westerners, seemingly bolstering that idea.", "source": An indictment of the Wall Street Journal reporter has been finalized and his case was filed to the Sverdlovsky Regional Court in the city about 870 miles east of Moscow, according to Russia's Prosecutor General's office.\n\nGershkovich is accused of \"gathering secret information\" for the CIA about Uralvagonzavod, a facility in the Sverdlovsk region that produces and repairs military equipment, the Prosecutor General's office said in a statement, revealing for the first time the details of the accusations against him.\n\nThe officials didn't provide any evidence to back up the accusations. There was no word on when the trial would begin.\n\nGershkovich was detained while on a reporting trip to Yekaterinburg in March 2023 and accused of spying for the United States. The reporter, his employer and the U.S. government denied the allegations, and Washington designated him as wrongfully detained.\n\nThe Federal Security Service, or FSB, alleged at the time he was acting on U.S. orders to collect state secrets but also provided no evidence.\n\nPresident Vladimir Putin has said he believed a deal could be reached to free Gershkovich, hinting he would be open to swapping him for a Russian national imprisoned in Germany, which appeared to be Vadim Krasikov. He was serving a life sentence for the 2019 killing in Berlin of a Georgian citizen of Chechen descent.\n\nAsked last week by The Associated Press about Gershkovich, Putin said the U.S. is \"taking energetic steps\" to secure his release. He said any such releases \"aren't decided via mass media\" but through a \"discreet, calm and professional approach.\"\n\n\"And they certainly should be decided only on the basis of reciprocity,\" he added in an allusion to a potential prisoner swap.\n\nGershkovich faces up to 20 years in prison if convicted.\n\nHe was the first U.S. journalist taken into custody on espionage charges since Nicholas Daniloff in 1986 at the height of the Cold War. Gershkovich's arrest shocked foreign journalists in Russia, even though the country had enacted increasingly repressive laws on freedom of speech after sending troops into Ukraine.\n\nThe son of Soviet emigres who settled in New Jersey, Gershkovich was fluent in Russian and moved to the country in 2017 to work for The Moscow Times newspaper before being hired by the Journal in 2022.\n\nSince his arrest, Gershkovich has been held at Moscow's Lefortovo Prison, a notorious czarist-era prison used during Josef Stalin's purges, when executions were carried out in its basement.\n\nThe Biden administration has sought to negotiate his release, but Russia's Foreign Ministry said it would consider a prisoner swap only after a verdict in his trial.\n\nU.S. Ambassador Lynne Tracy, who regularly visited Gershkovich in prison and attended his court hearings, has called the charges against him \"fiction\" and said that Russia is \"using American citizens as pawns to achieve political {"uri": "8176497406", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-13", "time": "17:51:24", "dateTime": "2024-06-13T17:51:24Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-13T17:50:41Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8901960849761963, "url": "https://www.vindy.com/news/latest-news/2024/06/us-reporter-evan-gershkovich-jailed-in-russia-on-espionage-charges-to-stand-trial-officials-say/", "title": "US reporter Evan Gershkovich, jailed in Russia on espionage charges, to stand trial, officials say", "body": "Wall Street Journal reporter Evan Gershkovich stands in a glass cage in a courtroom at the First Appeals Court of General Jurisdiction in Moscow, Russia, April 23, 2024. Gershkovich, who has been jailed for over a year in Russia on espionage charges, will stand trial in the city of Yekaterinburg, authorities said Thursday June 13, 2024. (AP Photo/Alexander Zemlianichenko, File)\n\nMOSCOW (AP) -- U.S. journalist Evan Gershkovich, who has been jailed for over a year in Russia on espionage charges, will stand trial in the Ural Mountains city of Yekaterinburg, where he was detained, authorities said Thursday.\n\nAn indictment of The Wall Street Journal reporter has been finalized and his case was filed to the Sverdlovsky Regional Court in the city about 1,400 kilometers (870 miles) east of Moscow, according to Russia's Prosecutor General's office.\n\nGershkovich, 32, is accused of \"gathering secret information\" on orders from the CIA about Uralvagonzavod, a facility in the Sverdlovsk region that produces and repairs military equipment, the Prosecutor General's office said in a statement, revealing for the first time the details of the accusations against him.\n\nThe officials did not provide any evidence to back up the accusations. There was no word on when the trial would begin.\n\nThe Biden administration has sought to negotiate his release, but Russia's Foreign Ministry said Moscow would consider a prisoner swap only after a verdict in his trial.\n\nGershkovich was detained while on a reporting trip to Yekaterinburg in March 2023 and accused of spying for the United States. The reporter, his employer and the U.S. government denied the allegations, and Washington designated him as wrongfully detained.\n\nRussia's Federal Security Service, or FSB, alleged at the time that he was acting on U.S. orders to collect state secrets but also provided no evidence.\n\n\"Russia's latest move toward a sham trial is, while expected, deeply disappointing and still no less outrageous,\" a statement by Almar Latour, Dow Jones CEO and publisher of the Journal, and Emma Tucker, the Journal's editor in chief, said.\n\nThey added that the charges against Gershkovich were \"false and baseless.\"\n\n\"The Russian regime's smearing of Evan is repugnant, disgusting and based on calculated and transparent lies. Journalism is not a crime. Evan's case is an assault on free press,\" the statement said. \"We had hoped to avoid this moment and now expect the U.S. government to redouble efforts to get Evan released.\"\n\nRoger Carstens, the Biden administration's special presidential envoy who serves as the U.S. government's top hostage negotiator, said that though he had been hopeful about striking a deal to get Gershkovich home before this point, the latest development \"doesn't slow or stop us down.\"\n\n\"The bottom line is, this was not unexpected,\" he said.\n\nUralvagonzavod, a state tank and railroad car factory in the city of Nizhny Tagil, about 100 kilometers (60 miles) north of Yekaterinburg, became known in 2011-12 as a bedrock of support for President Vladimir Putin.\n\nPlant foreman Igor Kholmanskih appeared on Putin's annual phone-in program in December 2011 and denounced mass protests occurring in Moscow at the time as a threat to \"stability,\" proposing that he and his colleagues travel to the Russian capital to help suppress the unrest. A week later, Putin appointed Kholmanskikh to be his envoy in the region.\n\nPutin has said he believed a deal could be reached to free Gershkovich, hinting he would be open to swapping him for a Russian national imprisoned in Germany, which appeared to be Vadim Krasikov, who is serving a life sentence for the 2019 killing in Berlin of a Georgian citizen of Chechen descent.\n\nAsked last week by The Associated Press about Gershkovich, Putin said the U.S. is \"taking energetic steps\" to secure his release. He told international news agencies in St. Petersburg that any such releases \"aren't decided via mass media\" but through a \"discreet, calm and professional approach.\"\n\n\"And they certainly should be decided only on the basis of reciprocity,\" he added in an allusion to a potential prisoner swap.\n\nGershkovich faces up to 20 years in prison if convicted.\n\nHe was the first U.S. journalist taken into custody on espionage charges since Nicholas Daniloff in 1986 at the height of the Cold War. Gershkovich's arrest shocked foreign journalists in Russia, even though the country had enacted increasingly repressive laws on freedom of speech after sending troops into Ukraine.\n\nThe son of Soviet emigres who settled in New Jersey, Gershkovich was fluent in Russian and moved to the country in 2017 to work for The Moscow Times newspaper before being hired by the Journal in 2022.\n\nSince his arrest, Gershkovich has been held at Moscow's Lefortovo Prison, a notorious czarist-era prison used during Josef Stalin's purges, when executions were carried out in its basement.\n\nU.S. Ambassador Lynne Tracy, who regularly visited Gershkovich in prison and attended his court hearings, has called the charges against him \"fiction\" and said that Russia is \"using American citizens as pawns to achieve political ends.\"\n\nSince sending troops to Ukraine, Russian authorities have detained several U.S. nationals and other Westerners, seemingly bolstering that idea.", "source": {"uri": "8176279390", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-13", "time": "15:12:20", "dateTime": "2024-06-13T15:12:20Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-13T15:11:25Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8784313797950745, "url": "https://www.euronews.com/2024/06/13/us-journalist-evan-gershkovich-to-stand-trial-in-russia-on-espionage-charges", "title": "US journalist imprisoned in Russia to stand trial on espionage charges", "body": "Wall Street Journal reporter Gershkovich is accused by Russian authorities of collecting secret information for the CIA about Uralvagonzavod, a military equipment facility in the Sverdlovsk region.\n\nRussian authorities have announced that US journalist Evan Gershkovich, who has been jailed for over a year on espionage charges, will be standing trial in the Ural Mountains city of Yekaterinburg.\n\nAccording to Russia's Prosecutor General's office, an indictment of the Wall Street Journal reporter has been finalised and his case filed to the Sverdlovsky Regional Court in the city about 1,400 kilometres east of Moscow.\n\nGershkovich is accused of \"gathering secret information\" on orders from the CIA about Uralvagonzavod, a facility in the Sverdlovsk region that produces and repairs military equipment, the Prosecutor General's office said in a statement -- the first time details of of the allegations have been revealed.\n\nThe officials didn't provide any evidence to back up the accusations. There was no word on when the trial would begin.\n\nGershkovich was detained while on a reporting trip to Yekaterinburg in March 2023 and accused of spying for the US. The reporter, his employer and the US government denied the allegations, and Washington designated him as wrongfully detained.\n\nThe Federal Security Service, or FSB, alleged at the time he was acting on US orders to collect state secrets but also provided no evidence.\n\nUralvagonzavod, a state tank and railroad car factory in the city of Nizhny Tagil about 100 kilometres north of Yekaterinburg, became known in 2011-12 as a bedrock of support for President Vladimir Putin.\n\nPlant foreman Igor Kholmanskih appeared on Putin's annual phone-in program in December 2011 and denounced mass protests occurring in Moscow at the time as a threat to \"stability\", proposing that he and his colleagues travel to the capital to help suppress the unrest. A week later, Putin appointed Kholmanskikh to be his envoy in the region.\n\nGershkovich faces up to 20 years in prison if convicted.\n\nHe was the first US journalist taken into custody on espionage charges since Nicholas Daniloff in 1986 at the height of the Cold War. Gershkovich's arrest shocked foreign journalists in Russia, even though the country had enacted increasingly repressive laws on freedom of speech after sending troops into Ukraine.\n\nThe son of Soviet emigres who settled in New Jersey, Gershkovich was fluent in Russian and moved to the country in 2017 to work for The Moscow Times newspaper before being hired by the WS Journal in 2022.\n\nSince his arrest, Gershkovich has been held at Moscow's Lefortovo Prison, a notorious czarist-era prison used during Josef Stalin's purges, when executions were carried out in its basement.\n\nThe Biden administration has sought to negotiate his release, but Russia's Foreign Ministry said it would consider a prisoner swap only after a verdict in his trial.\n\nSince the start of its full-scale invasion of Ukraine in February 2022, Russian authorities have detained several US nationals and other Westerners.\n\nUS Ambassador Lynne Tracy, who regularly visited Gershkovich in prison and attended his court hearings, has called the charges against him \"fiction\" and said that Russia is \"using American citizens as pawns to achieve political ends.\"\n\nPutin has said he believes a deal could be reached to free Gershkovich, hinting he would be open to swapping him for a Russian national imprisoned in Germany, which appeared to be Vadim Krasikov. He was serving a life sentence for the 2019 killing in Berlin of a Georgian citizen of Chechen descent.\n\nAsked last week by The Associated Press about Gershkovich, Putin said the US is \"taking energetic steps\" to secure his release. He told international news agencies in St Petersburg that any such releases \"aren't decided via mass media\" but through a \"discreet, calm and professional approach\".\n\n\"And they certainly should be decided only on the basis of reciprocity,\" he added in an allusion to a potential prisoner swap.", "source": {"uri": "euronews.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Euronews English"}, "authors": There was no word on when the trial would begin.\n\nGershkovich was detained while on a reporting trip to Yekaterinburg in March 2023 and accused of spying for the United States. The reporter, his employer and the US government denied the allegations, and Washington designated him as wrongfully detained.\n\nThe Federal Security Service, or FSB, alleged at the time he was acting on US orders to collect state secrets but also provided no evidence.\n\nPresident Vladimir Putin has said he believed a deal could be reached to free Gershkovich, hinting he would be open to swapping him for a Russian national imprisoned in Germany, which appeared to be Vadim Krasikov. He was serving a life sentence for the 2019 killing in Berlin of a Georgian citizen of Chechen descent.\n\nAsked last week by The Associated Press about Gershkovich, Putin said the US is \"taking energetic steps\" to secure his release. He said any such releases \"aren't decided via mass media\" but through a \"discreet, calm and professional approach.\"\n\n\"And they certainly should be decided only on the basis of reciprocity,\" he added in an allusion to a potential prisoner swap.\n\nGershkovich faces up to 20 years in prison if convicted.\n\nHe was the first US journalist taken into custody on espionage charges since Nicholas Daniloff in 1986, at the height of the Cold War.\n\nGershkovich's arrest shocked foreign journalists in Russia, even though the country had enacted increasingly repressive laws on freedom of speech after sending troops into Ukraine.\n\nThe son of Soviet emigres who settled in New Jersey, Gershkovich was fluent in Russian and moved to the country in 2017 to work for The Moscow Times newspaper before being hired by the Journal in 2022.\n\nSince his arrest, Gershkovich has been held at Moscow's Lefortovo Prison, a notorious czarist-era prison used during Josef Stalin's purges, when executions were carried out in its basement.\n\nThe Biden administration has sought to negotiate his release, but Russia's Foreign Ministry said it would consider a prisoner swap only after a verdict in his trial.\n\nUS Ambassador Lynne Tracy, who regularly visited Gershkovich in prison and attended his court hearings, has called the charges against him \"fiction\" and said that Russia is \"using American citizens as pawns to achieve political ends.\"\n\nSince sending troops to Ukraine, Russian authorities have detained several US nationals and other Westerners, seemingly bolstering that {"uri": "8176181696", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-13", "time": "14:08:24", "dateTime": "2024-06-13T14:08:24Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-13T14:07:50Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8745098114013672, "url": "https://www.scmp.com/news/world/russia-central-asia/article/3266523/jailed-russia-us-reporter-evan-gershkovich-be-tried-spying-charges-officials-say", "title": "Jailed US reporter Gershkovich to be tried on spying charges in Russia: officials", "body": "Gershkovich is accused of \u2018gathering secret information\u2019 for the CIA about a facility that produces and repairs military equipment\n\nUS journalist Evan Gershkovich, who has been jailed for over a year in Russia on espionage charges, will stand trial in the Ural Mountains city of Yekaterinburg, authorities said on Thursday.\n\nAn indictment of the Wall Street Journal reporter has been finalised, and his case was filed to the Sverdlovsky Regional Court in the city about 1,400 kilometres (870 miles) east of Moscow, according to Russia\u2019s Prosecutor General\u2019s office.\n\nGershkovich is accused of \u201cgathering secret information\u201d for the CIA about Uralvagonzavod, a facility in the Sverdlovsk region that produces and repairs military equipment, the Prosecutor General\u2019s office said in a statement, revealing for the first time the details of the accusations against him.\n\nThe officials didn\u2019t provide any evidence to back up the accusations. There was no word on when the trial would begin.\n\nGershkovich was detained while on a reporting trip to Yekaterinburg in March 2023 and accused of spying for the United States. The reporter, his employer and the US government denied the allegations, and Washington designated him as wrongfully detained.\n\nThe Federal Security Service, or FSB, alleged at the time he was acting on US orders to collect state secrets but also provided no evidence.\n\nPresident Vladimir Putin has said he believed a deal could be reached to free Gershkovich, hinting he would be open to swapping him for a Russian national imprisoned in Germany, which appeared to be Vadim Krasikov. He was serving a life sentence for the 2019 killing in Berlin of a Georgian citizen of Chechen descent.\n\nAsked last week by Associated Press about Gershkovich, Putin said the US is \u201ctaking energetic steps\u201d to secure his release. He said any such releases \u201caren\u2019t decided via mass media\u201d but through a \u201cdiscreet, calm and professional approach.\u201d\n\n\u201cAnd they certainly should be decided only on the basis of reciprocity,\u201d he added, in an allusion to a potential prisoner swap.\n\nGershkovich faces up to 20 years in prison if convicted.\n\nHe was the first US journalist taken into custody on espionage charges since Nicholas Daniloff in 1986 at the height of the Cold War. Gershkovich\u2019s arrest shocked foreign journalists in Russia, even though the country had enacted increasingly repressive laws on freedom of speech after sending troops into Ukraine.\n\nThe son of Soviet \u00e9migr\u00e9s who settled in New Jersey, Gershkovich was fluent in Russian and moved to the country in 2017 to work for The Moscow Times newspaper before being hired by the Journal in 2022.\n\nSince his arrest, Gershkovich has been held at Moscow\u2019s Lefortovo Prison, a notorious czarist-era prison used during Josef Stalin\u2019s purges, when executions were carried out in its basement.\n\nThe Biden administration has sought to negotiate his release, but Russia\u2019s Foreign Ministry said it would consider a prisoner swap only after a verdict in his trial.\n\nUS Ambassador Lynne Tracy, who regularly visited Gershkovich in prison and attended his court hearings, has called the charges against him \u201cfiction\u201d and said that Russia is \u201cusing American citizens as pawns to achieve political ends.\u201d\n\nSince sending troops to Ukraine, Russian authorities have detained several US nationals and other Westerners, seemingly bolstering that idea.\n\nAdditional {"uri": "8176151280", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-13", "time": "14:03:52", "dateTime": "2024-06-13T14:03:52Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-13T13:49:10Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8745098114013672, "url": "https://www.dailymail.co.uk/wires/ap/article-13526553/US-reporter-Evan-Gershkovich-jailed-Russia-espionage-charges-stand-trial-officials-say.html", "title": "US reporter Evan Gershkovich, jailed in Russia on espionage...", "body": "MOSCOW (AP) - U.S. journalist Evan Gershkovich, who has been jailed for over a year in Russia on espionage charges, will stand trial in the Ural Mountains city of Yekaterinburg, authorities said Thursday.\n\nAn indictment of the Wall Street Journal reporter has been finalized and his case was filed to the Sverdlovsky Regional Court in the city about 1,400 kilometers (870 miles) east of Moscow, according to Russia\u00b4s Prosecutor General\u00b4s office.\n\nGershkovich is accused of \"gathering secret information\" on orders from the CIA about Uralvagonzavod, a facility in the Sverdlovsk region that produces and repairs military equipment, the Prosecutor General\u00b4s office said in a statement, revealing for the first time the details of the accusations against him.\n\nThe officials didn\u00b4t provide any evidence to back up the accusations. There was no word on when the trial would begin.\n\nGershkovich was detained while on a reporting trip to Yekaterinburg in March 2023 and accused of spying for the United States. The reporter, his employer and the U.S. government denied the allegations, and Washington designated him as wrongfully detained.\n\nThe Federal Security Service, or FSB, alleged at the time he was acting on U.S. orders to collect state secrets but also provided no evidence.\n\nFILE - Wall Street Journal reporter Evan Gershkovich stands in a glass cage in a courtroom at the First Appeals Court of General Jurisdiction in Moscow, Russia, April 23, 2024. Gershkovich, who has been jailed for over a year in Russia on espionage charges, will stand trial in the city of Yekaterinburg, authorities said Thursday June 13, 2024. (AP Photo/Alexander Zemlianichenko, File)\n\nUralvagonzavod, a state tank and railroad car factory in the city of Nizhny Tagil about 100 kilometers (60 miles) north of Yekaterinburg, became known in 2011-12 as a bedrock of support for President Vladimir Putin.\n\nPlant foreman Igor Kholmanskih appeared on Putin\u00b4s annual phone-in program in December 2011 and denounced mass protests occurring in Moscow at the time as a threat to \"stability,\" proposing that he and his colleagues travel to the capital to help suppress the unrest. A week later, Putin appointed Kholmanskikh to be his envoy in the region.\n\nPutin has said he believed a deal could be reached to free Gershkovich, hinting he would be open to swapping him for a Russian national imprisoned in Germany, which appeared to be Vadim Krasikov. He was serving a life sentence for the 2019 killing in Berlin of a Georgian citizen of Chechen descent.\n\nAsked last week by The Associated Press about Gershkovich, Putin said the U.S. is \"taking energetic steps\" to secure his release. He told international news agencies in St. Petersburg that any such releases \"aren\u00b4t decided via mass media\" but through a \"discreet, calm and professional approach.\"\n\n\"And they certainly should be decided only on the basis of reciprocity,\" he added in an allusion to a potential prisoner swap.\n\nGershkovich faces up to 20 years in prison if convicted.\n\nHe was the first U.S. journalist taken into custody on espionage charges since Nicholas Daniloff in 1986 at the height of the Cold War. Gershkovich\u00b4s arrest shocked foreign journalists in Russia, even though the country had enacted increasingly repressive laws on freedom of speech after sending troops into Ukraine.\n\nThe son of Soviet emigres who settled in New Jersey, Gershkovich was fluent in Russian and moved to the country in 2017 to work for The Moscow Times newspaper before being hired by the Journal in 2022.\n\nSince his arrest, Gershkovich has been held at Moscow\u00b4s Lefortovo Prison, a notorious czarist-era prison used during Josef Stalin\u00b4s purges, when executions were carried out in its basement.\n\nThe Biden administration has sought to negotiate his release, but Russia\u00b4s Foreign Ministry said it would consider a prisoner swap only after a verdict in his trial.\n\nU.S. Ambassador Lynne Tracy, who regularly visited Gershkovich in prison and attended his court hearings, has called the charges against him \"fiction\" and said that Russia is \"using American citizens as pawns to achieve political ends.\"\n\nSince sending troops to Ukraine, Russian authorities have detained several U.S. nationals and other Westerners, seemingly bolstering that idea.\n\nFILE - Wall Street Journal reporter Evan Gershkovich stands in a glass cage in a courtroom at the First Appeals Court of General Jurisdiction in Moscow, Russia, April 23, 2024. Gershkovich, who has been jailed for over a year in Russia on espionage charges, will stand trial in the city of Yekaterinburg, authorities said Thursday June 13, 2024. {"uri": "2024-06-388573808", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-13", "time": "15:34:39", "dateTime": "2024-06-13T15:34:39Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-13T09:50:31Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8745098114013672, "url": "https://www.rocketcitynow.com/article/news/nation-world/us-reporter-evan-gershkovich-to-stand-trial-russian-officials-say/507-070e1f73-5779-494c-acba-d7e2dc9fa688", "title": "US reporter Evan Gershkovich, jailed in Russia on espionage charges, to stand trial, officials say", "body": "MOSCOW, Russia -- U.S. journalist Evan Gershkovich, who has been jailed for over a year in Russia on espionage charges, will stand trial in the Ural Mountains city of Yekaterinburg, authorities said Thursday.\n\nAn indictment of the Wall Street Journal reporter has been finalized and his case was filed to the Sverdlovsky Regional Court in the city about 1,400 kilometers (870 miles) east of Moscow, according to Russia's Prosecutor General's office.\n\nGershkovich is accused of \"gathering secret information\" on orders from the CIA about Uralvagonzavod, a facility in the Sverdlovsk region that produces and repairs military equipment, the Prosecutor General's office said in a statement, revealing for the first time the details of the accusations against him.\n\nThe officials didn't provide any evidence to back up the accusations. There was no word on when the trial would begin.\n\nThe Biden administration has sought to negotiate his release, but Russia's Foreign Ministry said it would consider a prisoner swap only after a verdict in his trial.\n\nGershkovich was detained while on a reporting trip to Yekaterinburg in March 2023 and accused of spying for the United States. The reporter, his employer and the U.S. government denied the allegations, and Washington designated him as wrongfully detained.\n\nThe Federal Security Service, or FSB, alleged at the time he was acting on U.S. orders to collect state secrets but also provided no evidence.\n\nUralvagonzavod, a state tank and railroad car factory in the city of Nizhny Tagil about 100 kilometers (60 miles) north of Yekaterinburg, became known in 2011-12 as a bedrock of support for President Vladimir Putin.\n\nPlant foreman Igor Kholmanskih appeared on Putin's annual phone-in program in December 2011 and denounced mass protests occurring in Moscow at the time as a threat to \"stability,\" proposing that he and his colleagues travel to the capital to help suppress the unrest. A week later, Putin appointed Kholmanskikh to be his envoy in the region.\n\nPutin has said he believed a deal could be reached to free Gershkovich, hinting he would be open to swapping him for a Russian national imprisoned in Germany, which appeared to be Vadim Krasikov. He was serving a life sentence for the 2019 killing in Berlin of a Georgian citizen of Chechen descent.\n\nAsked last week by The Associated Press about Gershkovich, Putin said the U.S. is \"taking energetic steps\" to secure his release. He told international news agencies in St. Petersburg that any such releases \"aren't decided via mass media\" but through a \"discreet, calm and professional approach.\"\n\n\"And they certainly should be decided only on the basis of reciprocity,\" he added in an allusion to a potential prisoner swap.\n\nGershkovich faces up to 20 years in prison if convicted.\n\nHe was the first U.S. journalist taken into custody on espionage charges since Nicholas Daniloff in 1986 at the height of the Cold War. Gershkovich's arrest shocked foreign journalists in Russia, even though the country had enacted increasingly repressive laws on freedom of speech after sending troops into Ukraine.\n\nThe son of Soviet emigres who settled in New Jersey, Gershkovich was fluent in Russian and moved to the country in 2017 to work for The Moscow Times newspaper before being hired by the Journal in 2022.\n\nSince his arrest, Gershkovich has been held at Moscow's Lefortovo Prison, a notorious czarist-era prison used during Josef Stalin's purges, when executions were carried out in its basement.\n\nU.S. Ambassador Lynne Tracy, who regularly visited Gershkovich in prison and attended his court hearings, has called the charges against him \"fiction\" and said that Russia is \"using American citizens as pawns to achieve political ends.\"\n\nSince sending troops to Ukraine, Russian authorities have detained several U.S. nationals and other Westerners, seemingly bolstering that idea.", "source": {"uri": "8176692407", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-13", "time": "20:52:14", "dateTime": "2024-06-13T20:52:14Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-13T20:51:02Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8745098114013672, "url": "https://www.nbcnewyork.com/news/national-international/evan-gershkovich-russia-trial-espionage-charges/5505312/", "title": "Reporter Evan Gershkovich to stand trial in Russia on espionage charges, officials say", "body": "The Wall Street Journal's publisher called the move 'deeply disappointing' and 'outrageous' in a statement Thursday\n\nU.S. journalist Evan Gershkovich, who has been jailed for over a year in Russia on espionage charges, will stand trial in the Ural Mountains city of Yekaterinburg, where he was detained, authorities said Thursday.\n\nAn indictment of The Wall Street Journal reporter has been finalized and his case was filed to the Sverdlovsky Regional Court in the city about 1,400 kilometers (870 miles) east of Moscow, according to Russia's Prosecutor General's office. There was no word on when the trial would begin.\n\nGershkovich, 32, is accused of \"gathering secret information\" on orders from the CIA about Uralvagonzavod, a facility in the Sverdlovsk region that produces and repairs military equipment, the Prosecutor General's office said in a statement, revealing for the first time the details of the accusations against him.\n\nGershkovich was detained while on a reporting trip to Yekaterinburg in March 2023 and accused of spying for the United States. The reporter, his employer and the U.S. government denied the allegations, and Washington designated him as wrongfully detained.\n\nRussia's Federal Security Service, or FSB, alleged after arresting Gershkovich that he was acting on U.S. orders to collect state secrets but provided no evidence to back up the accusations.\n\nThe U.S. State Department spokesman Matthew Miller slammed the development, saying there was \"absolutely zero credibility to those charges\" and adding that the U.S. government would continue to work to bring Gershkovich home.\n\n\"Evan has done nothing wrong. He should never have been arrested in the first place. Journalism is not a crime,\" Miller said. \"The charges against him are false. And the Russian government knows that they're false. He should be released immediately.\"\n\nThe Biden administration has sought to negotiate his release, but Russia's Foreign Ministry said Moscow would consider a prisoner swap only after a verdict in his trial.\n\n\"Russia's latest move toward a sham trial is, while expected, deeply disappointing and still no less outrageous,\" a statement by Almar Latour, Dow Jones CEO and publisher of the Journal, and Emma Tucker, the Journal's editor in chief, said.\n\nThey added that the charges against Gershkovich were \"false and baseless.\"\n\n\"The Russian regime's smearing of Evan is repugnant, disgusting and based on calculated and transparent lies. Journalism is not a crime. Evan's case is an assault on free press,\" the statement said. \"We had hoped to avoid this moment and now expect the U.S. government to redouble efforts to get Evan released.\"\n\nRoger Carstens, the Biden administration's special presidential envoy who serves as the U.S. government's top hostage negotiator, said that though he had been hopeful about striking a deal to get Gershkovich home before this point, the latest development \"doesn't slow or stop us down.\"\n\n\"The bottom line is, this was not unexpected,\" he said.\n\nUralvagonzavod, a state tank and railroad car factory in the city of Nizhny Tagil, about 100 kilometers (60 miles) north of Yekaterinburg, became known in 2011-12 as a bedrock of support for President Vladimir Putin.\n\nPlant foreman Igor Kholmanskih appeared on Putin's annual phone-in program in December 2011 and denounced mass protests occurring in Moscow at the time as a threat to \"stability,\" proposing that he and his colleagues travel to the Russian capital to help suppress the unrest. A week later, Putin appointed Kholmanskikh to be his envoy in the region.\n\nPutin has said he believed a deal could be reached to free Gershkovich, hinting he would be open to swapping him for a Russian national imprisoned in Germany, which appeared to be Vadim Krasikov, who is serving a life sentence for the 2019 killing in Berlin of a Georgian citizen of Chechen descent.\n\nAsked last week by The Associated Press about Gershkovich, Putin said the U.S. is \"taking energetic steps\" to secure his release. He told international news agencies in St. Petersburg that any such releases \"aren't decided via mass media\" but through a \"discreet, calm and professional approach.\"\n\n\"And they certainly should be decided only on the basis of reciprocity,\" he added in an allusion to a potential prisoner swap.\n\nGershkovich faces up to 20 years in prison if convicted.\n\nHe was the first U.S. journalist taken into custody on espionage charges since Nicholas Daniloff in 1986 at the height of the Cold War. Gershkovich's arrest shocked foreign journalists in Russia, even though the country had enacted increasingly repressive laws on freedom of speech after sending troops into Ukraine.\n\nThe son of Soviet emigres who settled in New Jersey, Gershkovich was fluent in Russian and moved to the country in 2017 to work for The Moscow Times newspaper before being hired by the Journal in 2022.\n\nSince his arrest, Gershkovich has been held at Moscow's Lefortovo Prison, a notorious czarist-era prison used during Josef Stalin's purges, when executions were carried out in its basement.\n\nU.S. Ambassador Lynne Tracy, who regularly visited Gershkovich in prison and attended his court hearings, has called the charges against him \"fiction\" and said that Russia is \"using American citizens as pawns to achieve political ends.\"\n\nSince sending troops to Ukraine, Russian authorities have detained several U.S. nationals and other Westerners, seemingly bolstering that idea.", "source": {"uri": "2024-06-388602564", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-13", "time": "16:02:55", "dateTime": "2024-06-13T16:02:55Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-13T09:50:31Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8705882430076599, "url": "https://www.weareiowa.com/article/news/nation-world/us-reporter-evan-gershkovich-to-stand-trial-russian-officials-say/507-070e1f73-5779-494c-acba-d7e2dc9fa688", "title": "US reporter Evan Gershkovich, jailed in Russia on espionage charges, to stand trial, officials say", "body": "MOSCOW, Russia -- U.S. journalist Evan Gershkovich, who has been jailed for over a year in Russia on espionage charges, will stand trial in the Ural Mountains city of Yekaterinburg, where he was detained, authorities said Thursday.\n\nAn indictment of The Wall Street Journal reporter has been finalized and his case was filed to the Sverdlovsky Regional Court in the city about 1,400 kilometers (870 miles) east of Moscow, according to Russia's Prosecutor General's office.\n\nGershkovich, 32, is accused of \"gathering secret information\" on orders from the CIA about Uralvagonzavod, a facility in the Sverdlovsk region that produces and repairs military equipment, the Prosecutor General's office said in a statement, revealing for the first time the details of the accusations against him.\n\nThe officials didn't provide any evidence to back up the accusations. There was no word on when the trial would begin.\n\nThe Biden administration has sought to negotiate his release, but Russia's Foreign Ministry said Moscow would consider a prisoner swap only after a verdict in his trial.\n\nGershkovich was detained while on a reporting trip to Yekaterinburg in March 2023 and accused of spying for the United States. The reporter, his employer and the U.S. government denied the allegations, and Washington designated him as wrongfully detained.\n\nThe Federal Security Service, or FSB, alleged at the time he was acting on U.S. orders to collect state secrets but also provided no evidence.\n\n\"Russia's latest move toward a sham trial is, while expected, deeply disappointing and still no less outrageous,\" according to a statement by Almar Latour, Dow Jones CEO and publisher of the Journal, and Emma Tucker, the Journal's editor in chief.\n\nThey added that the charges against Gershkovich were \"false and baseless.\"\n\n\"The Russian regime's smearing of Evan is repugnant, disgusting and based on calculated and transparent lies. Journalism is not a crime. Evan's case is an assault on free press,\" the statement said. \"We had hoped to avoid this moment and now expect the U.S. government to redouble efforts to get Evan released.\"\n\nUralvagonzavod, a state tank and railroad car factory in the city of Nizhny Tagil about 100 kilometers (60 miles) north of Yekaterinburg, became known in 2011-12 as a bedrock of support for President Vladimir Putin.\n\nPlant foreman Igor Kholmanskih appeared on Putin's annual phone-in program in December 2011 and denounced mass protests occurring in Moscow at the time as a threat to \"stability,\" proposing that he and his colleagues travel to the capital to help suppress the unrest. A week later, Putin appointed Kholmanskikh to be his envoy in the region.\n\nPutin has said he believed a deal could be reached to free Gershkovich, hinting he would be open to swapping him for a Russian national imprisoned in Germany, which appeared to be Vadim Krasikov. He was serving a life sentence for the 2019 killing in Berlin of a Georgian citizen of Chechen descent.\n\nAsked last week by The Associated Press about Gershkovich, Putin said the U.S. is \"taking energetic steps\" to secure his release. He told international news agencies in St. Petersburg that any such releases \"aren't decided via mass media\" but through a \"discreet, calm and professional approach.\"\n\n\"And they certainly should be decided only on the basis of reciprocity,\" he added in an allusion to a potential prisoner swap.\n\nGershkovich faces up to 20 years in prison if convicted.\n\nHe was the first U.S. journalist taken into custody on espionage charges since Nicholas Daniloff in 1986 at the height of the Cold War. Gershkovich's arrest shocked foreign journalists in Russia, even though the country had enacted increasingly repressive laws on freedom of speech after sending troops into Ukraine.\n\nThe son of Soviet emigres who settled in New Jersey, Gershkovich was fluent in Russian and moved to the country in 2017 to work for The Moscow Times newspaper before being hired by the Journal in 2022.\n\nSince his arrest, Gershkovich has been held at Moscow's Lefortovo Prison, a notorious czarist-era prison used during Josef Stalin's purges, when executions were carried out in its basement.\n\nU.S. Ambassador Lynne Tracy, who regularly visited Gershkovich in prison and attended his court hearings, has called the charges against him \"fiction\" and said that Russia is \"using American citizens as pawns to achieve political ends.\"\n\nSince sending troops to Ukraine, Russian authorities have detained several U.S. nationals and other Westerners, seemingly bolstering that idea.", "source": There was no word on when the trial would begin.\n\nThe Biden administration has sought to negotiate his release, but Russia's Foreign Ministry said Moscow would consider a prisoner swap only after a verdict in his trial.\n\nGershkovich was detained while on a reporting trip to Yekaterinburg in March 2023 and accused of spying for the United States. A week later, Putin appointed Kholmanskikh to be his envoy in the region.\n\nPutin has said he believed a deal could be reached to free Gershkovich, hinting he would be open to swapping him for a Russian national imprisoned in Germany, which appeared to be Vadim Krasikov. He was serving a life sentence for the 2019 killing in Berlin of a Georgian citizen of Chechen descent.\n\nAsked last week by The Associated Press about Gershkovich, Putin said the U.S. is \"taking energetic steps\" to secure his release. He told international news agencies in St. Petersburg that any such releases \"aren't decided via mass media\" but through a \"discreet, calm and professional approach.\"\n\n\"And they certainly should be decided only on the basis of reciprocity,\" he added in an allusion to a potential prisoner swap.\n\nGershkovich faces up to 20 years in prison if convicted.\n\nHe was the first U.S. journalist taken into custody on espionage charges since Nicholas Daniloff in 1986 at the height of the Cold War. Gershkovich has been charged with espionage.\n\nThe officials didn't provide any evidence to back up the accusations.\n\nGershkovich was detained while on a reporting trip to Yekaterinburg in March 2023 and accused of spying for the U.S. The Federal Security Service, or FSB, alleged at the time he was acting on U.S. orders to collect state secrets but also provided no evidence. Washington designated him as wrongfully detained.\n\nHe was the first U.S. journalist taken into custody on espionage charges since Nicholas Daniloff in 1986 at the height of the Cold War. Gershkovich's arrest shocked foreign journalists in Russia, even though the country had enacted increasingly repressive laws on freedom of speech after sending troops into Ukraine.\n\nCopyright 2024 The Associated Press. {"uri": "8176388122", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-13", "time": "16:26:30", "dateTime": "2024-06-13T16:26:30Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-13T16:25:45Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8666666746139526, "url": "https://www.breakingnews.ie/world/us-reporter-evan-gershkovich-held-in-russia-on-espionage-charges-to-face-trial-1637887.html", "title": "US reporter Evan Gershkovich, held in Russia on espionage charges, to face trial | BreakingNews.ie", "body": "US journalist Evan Gershkovich, who has been jailed for more than a year in Russia on espionage charges, will stand trial in the Ural Mountains city of Yekaterinburg, where he was detained, authorities said.\n\nAn indictment of The Wall Street Journal reporter has been finalised and his case was filed to the Sverdlovsky Regional Court in the city about 1,400 kilometres (870 miles) east of Moscow, according to Russia's Prosecutor General's Office.\n\nGershkovich, 32, is accused of \"gathering secret information\" on orders from the CIA about Uralvagonzavod, a facility in the Sverdlovsk region that produces and repairs military equipment, the Prosecutor General's Office said in a statement, revealing for the first time the details of the accusations against him.\n\nThe officials did not provide any evidence to back up the accusations.\n\nThere was no word on when the trial would begin.\n\nThe Biden administration has sought to negotiate his release, but Russia's Foreign Ministry said Moscow would consider a prisoner swap only after a verdict in his trial.\n\nGershkovich was detained while on a reporting trip to Yekaterinburg in March 2023 and accused of spying for the United States.\n\nThe reporter, his employer and the US government denied the allegations, and Washington designated him as wrongfully detained.\n\nThe Federal Security Service (FSB) alleged at the time he was acting on US orders to collect state secrets but also provided no evidence.\n\n\"Russia's latest move toward a sham trial is, while expected, deeply disappointing and still no less outrageous,\" according to a statement by Almar Latour, Dow Jones chief executive and publisher of the Journal, and Emma Tucker, the Journal's editor in chief.\n\nThey added that the charges against Gershkovich were \"false and baseless\".\n\n\"The Russian regime's smearing of Evan is repugnant, disgusting and based on calculated and transparent lies. Journalism is not a crime. Evan's case is an assault on free press,\" the statement said.\n\n\"We had hoped to avoid this moment and now expect the US government to redouble efforts to get Evan released.\"\n\nUralvagonzavod, a state tank and railroad car factory in the city of Nizhny Tagil about 100 kilometres (60 miles) north of Yekaterinburg, became known in 2011-12 as a bedrock of support for President Vladimir Putin.\n\nThe plant foreman appeared on Mr Putin's annual phone-in programme in December 2011 and denounced mass protests occurring in Moscow at the time as a threat to \"stability\", proposing that he and his colleagues travel to the capital to help suppress the unrest.\n\nA week later, Mr Putin appointed the plant foreman to be his envoy in the region.\n\nMr Putin has said he believed a deal could be reached to free Gershkovich, hinting he would be open to swapping him for a Russian national imprisoned in Germany, which appeared to be Vadim Krasikov.\n\nHe was serving a life sentence for the 2019 killing in Berlin of a Georgian citizen of Chechen descent.\n\nAsked last week by The Associated Press about Gershkovich, Mr Putin said the US is \"taking energetic steps\" to secure his release.\n\nHe told international news agencies in St Petersburg that any such releases \"aren't decided via mass media\" but through a \"discreet, calm and professional approach\".\n\n\"And they certainly should be decided only on the basis of reciprocity,\" he added in an allusion to a potential prisoner swap.\n\nGershkovich faces up to 20 years in prison if convicted.\n\nHe was the first US journalist taken into custody on espionage charges since Nicholas Daniloff in 1986 at the height of the Cold War.\n\nGershkovich's arrest shocked foreign journalists in Russia, even though the country had enacted increasingly repressive laws on freedom of speech after sending troops into Ukraine.\n\nThe son of Soviet emigres who settled in New Jersey, Gershkovich was fluent in Russian and moved to the country in 2017 to work for The Moscow Times newspaper before being hired by the Journal in 2022.\n\nSince his arrest, Gershkovich has been held at Moscow's Lefortovo Prison, a notorious tsarist-era prison used during Joseph Stalin's purges, when executions were carried out in its basement.\n\nUS ambassador Lynne Tracy, who regularly visited Gershkovich in prison and attended his court hearings, has called the charges against him \"fiction\" and said that Russia is \"using American citizens as pawns to achieve political ends\".\n\nSince sending troops to Ukraine, Russian authorities have detained several US nationals and other Westerners, seemingly bolstering that idea.", "source": {"uri": "breakingnews.ie", "dataType": "news", "title": "Breaking News.ie"}, "authors": {"uri": "8176386315", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-13", "time": "16:26:29", "dateTime": "2024-06-13T16:26:29Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-13T16:24:21Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8666666746139526, "url": "https://jerseyeveningpost.com/morenews/worldnews/2024/06/13/us-reporter-evan-gershkovich-held-in-russia-on-espionage-charges-to-face-trial/", "title": "US reporter Evan Gershkovich, held in Russia on espionage charges, to face trial", "body": "US journalist Evan Gershkovich, who has been jailed for more than a year in Russia on espionage charges, will stand trial in the Ural Mountains city of Yekaterinburg, where he was detained, authorities said.\n\nAn indictment of The Wall Street Journal reporter has been finalised and his case was filed to the Sverdlovsky Regional Court in the city about 1,400 kilometres (870 miles) east of Moscow, according to Russia's Prosecutor General's Office.\n\nGershkovich, 32, is accused of \"gathering secret information\" on orders from the CIA about Uralvagonzavod, a facility in the Sverdlovsk region that produces and repairs military equipment, the Prosecutor General's Office said in a statement, revealing for the first time the details of the accusations against him.\n\nThere was no word on when the trial would begin.\n\nThe Biden administration has sought to negotiate his release, but Russia's Foreign Ministry said Moscow would consider a prisoner swap only after a verdict in his trial.\n\nGershkovich was detained while on a reporting trip to Yekaterinburg in March 2023 and accused of spying for the United States.\n\nThe reporter, his employer and the US government denied the allegations, and Washington designated him as wrongfully detained.\n\nThe Federal Security Service (FSB) alleged at the time he was acting on US orders to collect state secrets but also provided no evidence.\n\n\"Russia's latest move toward a sham trial is, while expected, deeply disappointing and still no less outrageous,\" according to a statement by Almar Latour, Dow Jones chief executive and publisher of the Journal, and Emma Tucker, the Journal's editor in chief.\n\nThey added that the charges against Gershkovich were \"false and baseless\".\n\n\"We had hoped to avoid this moment and now expect the US government to redouble efforts to get Evan released.\"\n\nUralvagonzavod, a state tank and railroad car factory in the city of Nizhny Tagil about 100 kilometres (60 miles) north of Yekaterinburg, became known in 2011-12 as a bedrock of support for President Vladimir Putin.\n\nThe plant foreman appeared on Mr Putin's annual phone-in programme in December 2011 and denounced mass protests occurring in Moscow at the time as a threat to \"stability\", proposing that he and his colleagues travel to the capital to help suppress the unrest.\n\nA week later, Mr Putin appointed the plant foreman to be his envoy in the region.\n\nMr Putin has said he believed a deal could be reached to free Gershkovich, hinting he would be open to swapping him for a Russian national imprisoned in Germany, which appeared to be Vadim Krasikov.\n\nHe was serving a life sentence for the 2019 killing in Berlin of a Georgian citizen of Chechen descent.\n\nAsked last week by The Associated Press about Gershkovich, Mr Putin said the US is \"taking energetic steps\" to secure his release.\n\n\"And they certainly should be decided only on the basis of reciprocity,\" he added in an allusion to a potential prisoner swap.\n\nGershkovich faces up to 20 years in prison if convicted.\n\nHe was the first US journalist taken into custody on espionage charges since Nicholas Daniloff in 1986 at the height of the Cold War.\n\nGershkovich's arrest shocked foreign journalists in Russia, even though the country had enacted increasingly repressive laws on freedom of speech after sending troops into Ukraine.\n\nThe son of Soviet emigres who settled in New Jersey, Gershkovich was fluent in Russian and moved to the country in 2017 to work for The Moscow Times newspaper before being hired by the Journal in 2022.\n\nSince his arrest, Gershkovich has been held at Moscow's Lefortovo Prison, a notorious tsarist-era prison used during Joseph Stalin's purges, when executions were carried out in its basement.\n\nUS ambassador Lynne Tracy, who regularly visited Gershkovich in prison and attended his court hearings, has called the charges against him \"fiction\" and said that Russia is \"using American citizens as pawns to achieve political ends\".\n\nSince sending troops to Ukraine, Russian authorities have detained several US nationals and other Westerners, seemingly bolstering that idea.", "source": {"uri": "jerseyeveningpost.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Jersey Evening Post"}, {"uri": "8176240140", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-13", "time": "14:45:55", "dateTime": "2024-06-13T14:45:55Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-13T14:45:26Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8627451062202454, "url": "https://www.pressherald.com/2024/06/13/reporter-evan-gershkovich-jailed-in-russia-on-espionage-charges-to-stand-trial/", "title": "Reporter Evan Gershkovich, jailed in Russia on espionage charges, to stand trial", "body": "Wall Street Journal reporter Evan Gershkovich, left, stands in a glass cage in a courtroom at the First Appeals Court of General Jurisdiction on April 23 in Moscow, Russia. Alexander Zemlianichenko/Associated Press\n\nMOSCOW -- U.S. journalist Evan Gershkovich, who has been jailed for over a year in Russia on espionage charges, will stand trial in the Ural Mountains city of Yekaterinburg, authorities said Thursday.\n\nAn indictment of the Wall Street Journal reporter and Bowdoin College grad has been finalized and his case was filed to the Sverdlovsky Regional Court in the city about 870 miles east of Moscow, according to Russia's Prosecutor General's office.\n\nGershkovich is accused of \"gathering secret information\" on orders from the CIA about Uralvagonzavod, a facility in the Sverdlovsk region that produces and repairs military equipment, the Prosecutor General's office said in a statement, revealing for the first time the details of the accusations against him.\n\nRelated Read more on Bowdoin College graduate Evan Gershkovich\n\nThe officials didn't provide any evidence to back up the accusations. There was no word on when the trial would begin.\n\nThe Biden administration has sought to negotiate his release, but Russia's Foreign Ministry said it would consider a prisoner swap only after a verdict in his trial.\n\nGershkovich was detained while on a reporting trip to Yekaterinburg in March 2023 and accused of spying for the United States. The reporter, his employer and the U.S. government denied the allegations, and Washington designated him as wrongfully detained.\n\nAdvertisement\n\nThe Federal Security Service, or FSB, alleged at the time he was acting on U.S. orders to collect state secrets but also provided no evidence.\n\nUralvagonzavod, a state tank and railroad car factory in the city of Nizhny Tagil about 60 miles north of Yekaterinburg, became known in 2011-12 as a bedrock of support for President Vladimir Putin.\n\nPlant foreman Igor Kholmanskih appeared on Putin's annual phone-in program in December 2011 and denounced mass protests occurring in Moscow at the time as a threat to \"stability,\" proposing that he and his colleagues travel to the capital to help suppress the unrest. A week later, Putin appointed Kholmanskikh to be his envoy in the region.\n\nPutin has said he believed a deal could be reached to free Gershkovich, hinting he would be open to swapping him for a Russian national imprisoned in Germany, which appeared to be Vadim Krasikov. He was serving a life sentence for the 2019 killing in Berlin of a Georgian citizen of Chechen descent.\n\nAsked last week by The Associated Press about Gershkovich, Putin said the U.S. is \"taking energetic steps\" to secure his release. He told international news agencies in St. Petersburg that any such releases \"aren't decided via mass media\" but through a \"discreet, calm and professional approach.\"\n\n\"And they certainly should be decided only on the basis of reciprocity,\" he added in an allusion to a potential prisoner swap.\n\nAdvertisement\n\nGershkovich faces up to 20 years in prison if convicted.\n\nHe was the first U.S. journalist taken into custody on espionage charges since Nicholas Daniloff in 1986 at the height of the Cold War. Gershkovich's arrest shocked foreign journalists in Russia, even though the country had enacted increasingly repressive laws on freedom of speech after sending troops into Ukraine.\n\nThe son of Soviet emigres who settled in New Jersey, Gershkovich was fluent in Russian and moved to the country in 2017 to work for The Moscow Times newspaper before being hired by the Journal in 2022.\n\nSince his arrest, Gershkovich has been held at Moscow's Lefortovo Prison, a notorious czarist-era prison used during Josef Stalin's purges, when executions were carried out in its basement.\n\nU.S. Ambassador Lynne Tracy, who regularly visited Gershkovich in prison and attended his court hearings, has called the charges against him \"fiction\" and said that Russia is \"using American citizens as pawns to achieve political ends.\"\n\nSince sending troops to Ukraine, Russian authorities have detained several U.S. nationals and other Westerners, seemingly bolstering that idea.\n\nCopy the Story Link\n\nInvalid username/password.\n\nPlease check your email to confirm and complete your registration.\n\nCreate a commenting profile by providing an email address, password and display name. Gershkovich, The Wall Street Journal, the U.S. government and Gershkovich's many colleagues all vehemently dispute he was working as a spy and say that he was doing his job as a reporter.\n\nGershkovich was on a reporting trip in Yekaterinburg, the capital of the Sverdlovsk region, when he was arrested in March 2023.\n\nPreviously, prosecutors have alleged Gershkovich was working for a foreign intelligence service without specifying which one.\n\nThis is a developing story. {"uri": "8176382168", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-13", "time": "16:22:28", "dateTime": "2024-06-13T16:22:28Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-13T16:21:34Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8549019694328308, "url": "https://www.shropshirestar.com/news/world-news/2024/06/13/us-reporter-evan-gershkovich-held-in-russia-on-espionage-charges-to-face-trial/", "title": "US reporter Evan Gershkovich, held in Russia on espionage charges, to face trial", "body": "The 32-year-old was detained while on a reporting trip to Yekaterinburg in March 2023 and accused of spying for the United States.\n\nUS journalist Evan Gershkovich, who has been jailed for more than a year in Russia on espionage charges, will stand trial in the Ural Mountains city of Yekaterinburg, where he was detained, authorities said.\n\nAn indictment of The Wall Street Journal reporter has been finalised and his case was filed to the Sverdlovsky Regional Court in the city about 1,400 kilometres (870 miles) east of Moscow, according to Russia's Prosecutor General's Office.\n\nGershkovich, 32, is accused of \"gathering secret information\" on orders from the CIA about Uralvagonzavod, a facility in the Sverdlovsk region that produces and repairs military equipment, the Prosecutor General's Office said in a statement, revealing for the first time the details of the accusations against him.\n\nThe officials did not provide any evidence to back up the accusations.\n\nThere was no word on when the trial would begin.\n\nThe Biden administration has sought to negotiate his release, but Russia's Foreign Ministry said Moscow would consider a prisoner swap only after a verdict in his trial.\n\nGershkovich was detained while on a reporting trip to Yekaterinburg in March 2023 and accused of spying for the United States.\n\nThe reporter, his employer and the US government denied the allegations, and Washington designated him as wrongfully detained.\n\nThe Federal Security Service (FSB) alleged at the time he was acting on US orders to collect state secrets but also provided no evidence.\n\n\"Russia's latest move toward a sham trial is, while expected, deeply disappointing and still no less outrageous,\" according to a statement by Almar Latour, Dow Jones chief executive and publisher of the Journal, and Emma Tucker, the Journal's editor in chief.\n\nThey added that the charges against Gershkovich were \"false and baseless\".\n\n\"The Russian regime's smearing of Evan is repugnant, disgusting and based on calculated and transparent lies. Journalism is not a crime. Evan's case is an assault on free press,\" the statement said.\n\n\"We had hoped to avoid this moment and now expect the US government to redouble efforts to get Evan released.\"\n\nUralvagonzavod, a state tank and railroad car factory in the city of Nizhny Tagil about 100 kilometres (60 miles) north of Yekaterinburg, became known in 2011-12 as a bedrock of support for President Vladimir Putin.\n\nThe plant foreman appeared on Mr Putin's annual phone-in programme in December 2011 and denounced mass protests occurring in Moscow at the time as a threat to \"stability\", proposing that he and his colleagues travel to the capital to help suppress the unrest.\n\nA week later, Mr Putin appointed the plant foreman to be his envoy in the region.\n\nMr Putin has said he believed a deal could be reached to free Gershkovich, hinting he would be open to swapping him for a Russian national imprisoned in Germany, which appeared to be Vadim Krasikov.\n\nHe was serving a life sentence for the 2019 killing in Berlin of a Georgian citizen of Chechen descent.\n\nAsked last week by The Associated Press about Gershkovich, Mr Putin said the US is \"taking energetic steps\" to secure his release.\n\nHe told international news agencies in St Petersburg that any such releases \"aren't decided via mass media\" but through a \"discreet, calm and professional approach\".\n\n\"And they certainly should be decided only on the basis of reciprocity,\" he added in an allusion to a potential prisoner swap.\n\nGershkovich faces up to 20 years in prison if convicted.\n\nHe was the first US journalist taken into custody on espionage charges since Nicholas Daniloff in 1986 at the height of the Cold War.\n\nGershkovich's arrest shocked foreign journalists in Russia, even though the country had enacted increasingly repressive laws on freedom of speech after sending troops into Ukraine.\n\nThe son of Soviet emigres who settled in New Jersey, Gershkovich was fluent in Russian and moved to the country in 2017 to work for The Moscow Times newspaper before being hired by the Journal in 2022.\n\nSince his arrest, Gershkovich has been held at Moscow's Lefortovo Prison, a notorious tsarist-era prison used during Joseph Stalin's purges, when executions were carried out in its basement.\n\nUS ambassador Lynne Tracy, who regularly visited Gershkovich in prison and attended his court hearings, has called the charges against him \"fiction\" and said that Russia is \"using American citizens as pawns to achieve political ends\".\n\nSince sending troops to Ukraine, Russian authorities have detained several US nationals and other Westerners, seemingly bolstering that idea.", "source": {"uri": "shropshirestar.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Shropshire Star"}, {"uri": "2024-06-388488358", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-13", "time": "14:16:56", "dateTime": "2024-06-13T14:16:56Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-13T14:01:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8549019694328308, "url": "https://www.aol.com/news/wall-street-journal-reporter-evan-132759329.html", "title": "Wall Street Journal reporter Evan Gershkovich to stand trial in Russia on espionage charges", "body": "Wall Street Journal reporter Evan Gershkovich to stand trial in Russia on espionage charges\n\nTANYA STUKALOVA and PATRICK REEVELL\n\nJune 13, 2024 at 4:01 PM\n\nIn a setback to Wall Street Journal reporter Evan Gershkovich, the Russian prosecutor's office announced Thursday he will stand trial on espionage charges, officially ending any future pre-detention appeals.\n\n\"The Prosecutor General's Office of the Russian Federation has approved an indictment in the criminal case against US citizen Evan Gershkovich,\" the office said in a statement. \"The criminal case has been sent to the Sverdlovsk Regional Court for consideration on the merits.\"\n\nIt continued, \"The investigation established and documented that the American journalist of The Wall Street Journal, Gershkovich, on the instructions of the CIA in March 2023, collected secret information in the Sverdlovsk region about the activities of the defense enterprise JSC NPK Uralvagonzavod for the production and repair of military equipment.\"\n\nMORE: Biden, top lawmakers denounce Russia's yearlong detention of Evan Gershkovich\n\nGershkovich has denied he was involved in any espionage and the U.S. State Department has declared him to be wrongfully detained.\n\nThe statement Thursday marks the first time prosecutors have publicly accused Gershkovich of working for the CIA, alleging without evidence that he was collecting \"secret information\" on a tank factory in the Sverdlovsk region. Gershkovich, The Wall Street Journal, the U.S. government and Gershkovich's many colleagues all vehemently dispute he was working as a spy and say that he was doing his job as a reporter.\n\nGershkovich was on a reporting trip in Yekaterinburg, the capital of the Sverdlovsk region, when he was arrested in March 2023.\n\nPreviously, prosecutors have alleged Gershkovich was working for a foreign intelligence service without specifying which one.\n\nMORE: Parents of reporter Evan Gershkovich speak out 1 year into his Russian detainment: Exclusive\n\nIn March, Gershkovich's parents had told ABC News they were optimistic about progress in their son's case.\n\n\"We know that the U.S. government is taking Evan's case very seriously,\" his mother, Ella Milman, told \"Good Morning America\" co-anchor George Stephanopoulos in an exclusive sit-down interview.\n\n\"I think if you let the pessimism in ... the game is over,\" she said. \"And our saying in the family is we're moving forward. Moving forward.\"\n\nRussian President Vladimir Putin made his first comments on Gershkovich's detention in months on June 5.\n\n\"I know that the United States administration is really taking energetic steps for his release. This is true. But such issues are not resolved through the media,\" Putin said. \"They love such a quiet, calm professional approach and dialogue between the intelligence services.\"\n\nHe added, \"You know, you believe that he is innocent, and Russian law enforcement agencies and special services believe that he committed illegal actions, which are called espionage. I will not go into details.\"\n\nGershkovich most recently appeared in court in Moscow for a pretrial hearing on April 23 as part of an appeal against the spying charges. His appeal was denied and he was ordered held through at least June 30.\n\nThe reporter smiled and gave a thumb's up when asked by ABC News inside the courtroom how he was doing.\n\nABC News' Will Gretsky and Mark Osborne contributed to this report.\n\nWall Street Journal reporter Evan Gershkovich to stand trial in Russia on espionage charges originally appeared on abcnews.go.com", "source":
