{"uri": "8176203355", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-13", "time": "14:21:52", "dateTime": "2024-06-13T14:21:52Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-13T14:20:57Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8549019694328308, "url": "https://www.cbsnews.com/philadelphia/news/evan-gershkovich-russia-american-wall-street-journal-reporter-trial-espionage/", "title": "Russia says U.S. journalist Evan Gershkovich to stand trial on espionage charges", "body": "Moscow -- U.S. journalist Evan Gershkovich, who has been jailed for over a year in Russia on espionage charges, will stand trial in the Ural Mountains city of Yekaterinburg, authorities said Thursday. An indictment of the Wall Street Journal reporter has been finalized and his case was filed to the Sverdlovsky Regional Court in the city about 870 miles east of Moscow, according to Russia's Prosecutor General's office.\n\nGershkovich is accused of \"gathering secret information\" for the CIA about Uralvagonzavod, a facility in the Sverdlovsk region that produces and repairs military equipment, the Prosecutor General's office said in a statement, revealing for the first time the details of the accusations against him.\n\nThe officials didn't provide any evidence to back up the accusations. There was no word on when the trial would begin.\n\nGershkovich was detained while on a reporting trip to Yekaterinburg in March 2023 and accused of spying for the United States. The reporter, his employer and the U.S. government denied the allegations, and Washington designated him as wrongfully detained.\n\nThe Federal Security Service, or FSB, alleged at the time he was acting on U.S. orders to collect state secrets but also provided no evidence.\n\nPresident Vladimir Putin has said he believed a deal could be reached to free Gershkovich, hinting he would be open to swapping him for a Russian national imprisoned in Germany, which appeared to be Vadim Krasikov. He was serving a life sentence for the 2019 killing in Berlin of a Georgian citizen of Chechen descent.\n\nAsked last week by The Associated Press about Gershkovich, Putin said the U.S. is \"taking energetic steps\" to secure his release. He said any such releases \"aren't decided via mass media\" but through a \"discreet, calm and professional approach.\"\n\n\"And they certainly should be decided only on the basis of reciprocity,\" he added in an allusion to a potential prisoner swap.\n\nGershkovich faces up to 20 years in prison if convicted.\n\nHe was the first U.S. journalist taken into custody on espionage charges since Nicholas Daniloff in 1986 at the height of the Cold War. Gershkovich's arrest shocked foreign journalists in Russia, even though the country had enacted increasingly repressive laws on freedom of speech after sending troops into Ukraine.\n\nThe son of Soviet emigres who settled in New Jersey, Gershkovich was fluent in Russian and moved to the country in 2017 to work for The Moscow Times newspaper before being hired by the Journal in 2022.\n\nHis sister Danielle told CBS News' Lesley Stahl in March that the siblings have always been close. She said she was shattered when she learned he had been taken into custody in Russia.\n\n\"I got a call from my mom,\" she told CBS News. \"It's just, my stomach fell out, you know? Your heart stops. It's so hard to believe that something like that is actually real. And I remember my mom and I discussing the morning after: 'Is that really Evan, that photo that came out?' We didn't want to admit for a moment that that was him.\"\n\nStahl asked, \"Did you think [detention] was a possibility? Russia a year ago had already become dangerous. Other news organizations were pulling reporters out.\"\n\n\"I would say my whole family was nervous,\" she replied, but added that her brother would always remind his family that he was an accredited journalist in Russia -- and, therefore, supposedly safe.\n\n\"It's very unprecedented,\" Danielle said of her brother's arrest.\n\nBut what was unprecedented has become almost routine under Putin. Marine veteran Paul Whelan has been jailed in Russia for five years; Russian-American ballerina Ksenia Karelina was arrested in January, accused of treason for helping Ukraine; and basketball star Brittney Griner, imprisoned for nine months on drug charges, was finally freed in an exchange for a notorious arms dealer known as the \"Merchant of Death.\"\n\nSince his arrest, Gershkovich has been held at Moscow's Lefortovo Prison, a notorious czarist-era prison used during Josef Stalin's purges, when executions were carried out in its basement.\n\nThe Biden administration has sought to negotiate his release, but Russia's Foreign Ministry said it would consider a prisoner swap only after a verdict in his trial.\n\nU.S. Ambassador Lynne Tracy, who regularly visited Gershkovich in prison and attended his court hearings, has called the charges against him \"fiction\" and said Russia is \"using American citizens as pawns to achieve political ends.\"\n\nSince sending troops to Ukraine, Russian authorities have detained several U.S. nationals and other Westerners, seemingly bolstering that idea.", "source": {"uri": "cbsnews.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "CBS News"}, {"uri": "8176377328", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-13", "time": "16:18:50", "dateTime": "2024-06-13T16:18:50Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-13T16:17:45Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8470588326454163, "url": "https://gvwire.com/2024/06/13/us-reporter-evan-gershkovich-jailed-in-russia-on-espionage-charges-to-stand-trial-officials-say/", "title": "US Reporter Evan Gershkovich, Jailed in Russia on Espionage Charges, to Stand Trial, Officials Say", "body": "MOSCOW -- U.S. journalist Evan Gershkovich, who has been jailed for over a year in Russia on espionage charges, will stand trial in the Ural Mountains city of Yekaterinburg, where he was detained, authorities said Thursday.\n\nAn indictment of The Wall Street Journal reporter has been finalized and his case was filed to the Sverdlovsky Regional Court in the city about 1,400 kilometers (870 miles) east of Moscow, according to Russia's Prosecutor General's office.\n\nGershkovich, 32, is accused of \"gathering secret information\" on orders from the CIA about Uralvagonzavod, a facility in the Sverdlovsk region that produces and repairs military equipment, the Prosecutor General's office said in a statement, revealing for the first time the details of the accusations against him.\n\nThe officials didn't provide any evidence to back up the accusations. There was no word on when the trial would begin.\n\nThe Biden administration has sought to negotiate his release, but Russia's Foreign Ministry said Moscow would consider a prisoner swap only after a verdict in his trial.\n\nGershkovich was detained while on a reporting trip to Yekaterinburg in March 2023 and accused of spying for the United States. The reporter, his employer and the U.S. government denied the allegations, and Washington designated him as wrongfully detained.\n\nThe Federal Security Service, or FSB, alleged at the time he was acting on U.S. orders to collect state secrets but also provided no evidence.\n\nRelated Story: US Broadens Sanctions Against Russia, Aiming to Dissuade China from Engaging in ...\n\n\"Russia's latest move toward a sham trial is, while expected, deeply disappointing and still no less outrageous,\" according to a statement by Almar Latour, Dow Jones CEO and publisher of the Journal, and Emma Tucker, the Journal's editor in chief.\n\nThey added that the charges against Gershkovich were \"false and baseless.\"\n\n\"The Russian regime's smearing of Evan is repugnant, disgusting and based on calculated and transparent lies. Journalism is not a crime. Evan's case is an assault on free press,\" the statement said. \"We had hoped to avoid this moment and now expect the U.S. government to redouble efforts to get Evan released.\"\n\nRelated Story: Top Russian Military Officials Are Being Arrested. Why Is It Happening?\n\nUralvagonzavod, a state tank and railroad car factory in the city of Nizhny Tagil about 100 kilometers (60 miles) north of Yekaterinburg, became known in 2011-12 as a bedrock of support for President Vladimir Putin.\n\nPlant foreman Igor Kholmanskih appeared on Putin's annual phone-in program in December 2011 and denounced mass protests occurring in Moscow at the time as a threat to \"stability,\" proposing that he and his colleagues travel to the capital to help suppress the unrest. A week later, Putin appointed Kholmanskikh to be his envoy in the region.\n\nPutin has said he believed a deal could be reached to free Gershkovich, hinting he would be open to swapping him for a Russian national imprisoned in Germany. He was serving a life sentence for the 2019 killing in Berlin of a Georgian citizen of Chechen descent.\n\nAsked last week about Gershkovich, Putin said the U.S. is \"taking energetic steps\" to secure his release. He told international news agencies in St. Petersburg that any such releases \"aren't decided via mass media\" but through a \"discreet, calm and professional approach.\"\n\n\"And they certainly should be decided only on the basis of reciprocity,\" he added in an allusion to a potential prisoner swap.\n\nGershkovich faces up to 20 years in prison if convicted.\n\nRelated Story: Russian Missiles Kill 7 in Ukraine's Second-Largest City as ...\n\nHe was the first U.S. journalist taken into custody on espionage charges since Nicholas Daniloff in 1986 at the height of the Cold War. Gershkovich's arrest shocked foreign journalists in Russia, even though the country had enacted increasingly repressive laws on freedom of speech after sending troops into Ukraine.\n\nThe son of Soviet emigres who settled in New Jersey, Gershkovich was fluent in Russian and moved to the country in 2017 to work for The Moscow Times newspaper before being hired by the Journal in 2022.\n\nSince his arrest, Gershkovich has been held at Moscow's Lefortovo Prison, a notorious czarist-era prison used during Josef Stalin's purges, when executions were carried out in its basement.\n\nU.S. Ambassador Lynne Tracy, who regularly visited Gershkovich in prison and attended his court hearings, has called the charges against him \"fiction\" and said that Russia is \"using American citizens as pawns to achieve political ends.\"\n\nSince sending troops to Ukraine, Russian authorities have detained several U.S. nationals and other Westerners, seemingly bolstering that idea.", "source": {"uri": "8176565903", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-13", "time": "18:50:28", "dateTime": "2024-06-13T18:50:28Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-13T18:49:31Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8470588326454163, "url": "https://www.hindustantimes.com/world-news/us-news/us-reporter-evan-gershkovich-jailed-in-russia-on-espionage-charges-to-stand-trial-officials-say-101718303817402.html", "title": "US reporter Evan Gershkovich, jailed in Russia on espionage charges, to stand trial, officials say", "body": "An indictment of The Wall Street Journal reporter has been finalized and his case was filed to the Sverdlovsky Regional Court in the city about 1,400 kilometers east of Moscow, according to Russia's Prosecutor General's office. There was no word on when the trial would begin.\n\nGershkovich, 32, is accused of \"gathering secret information\" on orders from the CIA about Uralvagonzavod, a facility in the Sverdlovsk region that produces and repairs military equipment, the Prosecutor General's office said in a statement, revealing for the first time the details of the accusations against him.\n\nGershkovich was detained while on a reporting trip to Yekaterinburg in March 2023 and accused of spying for the United States. The reporter, his employer and the U.S. government denied the allegations, and Washington designated him as wrongfully detained.\n\nRussia's Federal Security Service, or FSB, alleged after arresting Gershkovich that he was acting on U.S. orders to collect state secrets but provided no evidence to back up the accusations.\n\nThe U.S. State Department spokesman Matthew Miller slammed the development, saying there was \"absolutely zero credibility to those charges\" and adding that the U.S. government would continue to work to bring Gershkovich home.\n\n\"Evan has done nothing wrong. He should never have been arrested in the first place. Journalism is not a crime,\" Miller said. \"The charges against him are false. And the Russian government knows that they're false. He should be released immediately.\"\n\nThe Biden administration has sought to negotiate his release, but Russia's Foreign Ministry said Moscow would consider a prisoner swap only after a verdict in his trial.\n\n\"Russia's latest move toward a sham trial is, while expected, deeply disappointing and still no less outrageous,\" a statement by Almar Latour, Dow Jones CEO and publisher of the Journal, and Emma Tucker, the Journal's editor in chief, said.\n\nThey added that the charges against Gershkovich were \"false and baseless.\"\n\n\"The Russian regime's smearing of Evan is repugnant, disgusting and based on calculated and transparent lies. Journalism is not a crime. Evan's case is an assault on free press,\" the statement said. \"We had hoped to avoid this moment and now expect the U.S. government to redouble efforts to get Evan released.\"\n\nRoger Carstens, the Biden administration's special presidential envoy who serves as the U.S. government's top hostage negotiator, said that though he had been hopeful about striking a deal to get Gershkovich home before this point, the latest development \"doesn't slow or stop us down.\"\n\n\"The bottom line is, this was not unexpected,\" he said.\n\nUralvagonzavod, a state tank and railroad car factory in the city of Nizhny Tagil, about 100 kilometers north of Yekaterinburg, became known in 2011-12 as a bedrock of support for President Vladimir Putin.\n\nPlant foreman Igor Kholmanskih appeared on Putin's annual phone-in program in December 2011 and denounced mass protests occurring in Moscow at the time as a threat to \"stability,\" proposing that he and his colleagues travel to the Russian capital to help suppress the unrest. A week later, Putin appointed Kholmanskikh to be his envoy in the region.\n\nPutin has said he believed a deal could be reached to free Gershkovich, hinting he would be open to swapping him for a Russian national imprisoned in Germany, which appeared to be Vadim Krasikov, who is serving a life sentence for the 2019 killing in Berlin of a Georgian citizen of Chechen descent.\n\nAsked last week by The Associated Press about Gershkovich, Putin said the U.S. is \"taking energetic steps\" to secure his release. He told international news agencies in St. Petersburg that any such releases \"aren't decided via mass media\" but through a \"discreet, calm and professional approach.\"\n\n\"And they certainly should be decided only on the basis of reciprocity,\" he added in an allusion to a potential prisoner swap.\n\nGershkovich faces up to 20 years in prison if convicted.\n\nHe was the first U.S. journalist taken into custody on espionage charges since Nicholas Daniloff in 1986 at the height of the Cold War. Gershkovich's arrest shocked foreign journalists in Russia, even though the country had enacted increasingly repressive laws on freedom of speech after sending troops into Ukraine.\n\nThe son of Soviet emigres who settled in New Jersey, Gershkovich was fluent in Russian and moved to the country in 2017 to work for The Moscow Times newspaper before being hired by the Journal in 2022.\n\nSince his arrest, Gershkovich has been held at Moscow's Lefortovo Prison, a notorious czarist-era prison used during Josef Stalin's purges, when executions were carried out in its basement.\n\nU.S. Ambassador Lynne Tracy, who regularly visited Gershkovich in prison and attended his court hearings, has called the charges against him \"fiction\" and said that Russia is \"using American citizens as pawns to achieve political ends.\"\n\nSince sending troops to Ukraine, Russian authorities have detained several U.S. nationals and other Westerners, seemingly bolstering that idea.", "source": {"uri": "8176409896", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-13", "time": "16:43:30", "dateTime": "2024-06-13T16:43:30Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-13T16:40:59Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.843137264251709, "url": "https://www.dailymail.co.uk/wires/pa/article-13527295/US-reporter-Evan-Gershkovich-held-Russia-espionage-charges-face-trial.html", "title": "US reporter Evan Gershkovich, held in Russia on espionage charges,...", "body": "US journalist Evan Gershkovich, who has been jailed for more than a year in Russia on espionage charges, will stand trial in the Ural Mountains city of Yekaterinburg, where he was detained, authorities said.\n\nAn indictment of The Wall Street Journal reporter has been finalised and his case was filed to the Sverdlovsky Regional Court in the city about 1,400 kilometres (870 miles) east of Moscow, according to Russia's Prosecutor General's Office.\n\nGershkovich, 32, is accused of \"gathering secret information\" on orders from the CIA about Uralvagonzavod, a facility in the Sverdlovsk region that produces and repairs military equipment, the Prosecutor General's Office said in a statement, revealing for the first time the details of the accusations against him.\n\nRussia's latest move toward a sham trial is, while expected, deeply disappointing and still no less outrageous Almar Latour and Emma Tucker\n\nThe officials did not provide any evidence to back up the accusations.\n\nThere was no word on when the trial would begin.\n\nThe Biden administration has sought to negotiate his release, but Russia's Foreign Ministry said Moscow would consider a prisoner swap only after a verdict in his trial.\n\nGershkovich was detained while on a reporting trip to Yekaterinburg in March 2023 and accused of spying for the United States.\n\nThe reporter, his employer and the US government denied the allegations, and Washington designated him as wrongfully detained.\n\nThe Federal Security Service (FSB) alleged at the time he was acting on US orders to collect state secrets but also provided no evidence.\n\n\"Russia's latest move toward a sham trial is, while expected, deeply disappointing and still no less outrageous,\" according to a statement by Almar Latour, Dow Jones chief executive and publisher of the Journal, and Emma Tucker, the Journal's editor in chief.\n\nThey added that the charges against Gershkovich were \"false and baseless\".\n\nRussian President Vladimir Putin (Mikhail Metzel, Sputnik, Kremlin Pool Photo via AP)\n\n\"The Russian regime's smearing of Evan is repugnant, disgusting and based on calculated and transparent lies. Journalism is not a crime. Evan's case is an assault on free press,\" the statement said.\n\n\"We had hoped to avoid this moment and now expect the US government to redouble efforts to get Evan released.\"\n\nUralvagonzavod, a state tank and railroad car factory in the city of Nizhny Tagil about 100 kilometres (60 miles) north of Yekaterinburg, became known in 2011-12 as a bedrock of support for President Vladimir Putin.\n\nThe plant foreman appeared on Mr Putin's annual phone-in programme in December 2011 and denounced mass protests occurring in Moscow at the time as a threat to \"stability\", proposing that he and his colleagues travel to the capital to help suppress the unrest.\n\nA week later, Mr Putin appointed the plant foreman to be his envoy in the region.\n\nMr Putin has said he believed a deal could be reached to free Gershkovich, hinting he would be open to swapping him for a Russian national imprisoned in Germany, which appeared to be Vadim Krasikov.\n\nHe was serving a life sentence for the 2019 killing in Berlin of a Georgian citizen of Chechen descent.\n\nAsked last week by The Associated Press about Gershkovich, Mr Putin said the US is \"taking energetic steps\" to secure his release.\n\nEvan Gershkovich in a glass cage in a courtroom at the First Appeals Court of General Jurisdiction in Moscow in April (Alexander Zemlianichenko/AP)\n\nHe told international news agencies in St Petersburg that any such releases \"aren't decided via mass media\" but through a \"discreet, calm and professional approach\".\n\n\"And they certainly should be decided only on the basis of reciprocity,\" he added in an allusion to a potential prisoner swap.\n\nGershkovich faces up to 20 years in prison if convicted.\n\nHe was the first US journalist taken into custody on espionage charges since Nicholas Daniloff in 1986 at the height of the Cold War.\n\nGershkovich's arrest shocked foreign journalists in Russia, even though the country had enacted increasingly repressive laws on freedom of speech after sending troops into Ukraine.\n\nThe son of Soviet emigres who settled in New Jersey, Gershkovich was fluent in Russian and moved to the country in 2017 to work for The Moscow Times newspaper before being hired by the Journal in 2022.\n\nSince his arrest, Gershkovich has been held at Moscow's Lefortovo Prison, a notorious tsarist-era prison used during Joseph Stalin's purges, when executions were carried out in its basement.\n\nUS ambassador Lynne Tracy, who regularly visited Gershkovich in prison and attended his court hearings, has called the charges against him \"fiction\" and said that Russia is \"using American citizens as pawns to achieve political ends\".\n\nSince sending troops to Ukraine, Russian authorities have detained several US {"uri": "8176387601", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-13", "time": "16:26:04", "dateTime": "2024-06-13T16:26:04Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-13T16:25:21Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.843137264251709, "url": "https://www.bpr.org/npr-news/2024-06-13/american-journalist-evan-gershkovich-to-stand-trial-on-espionage-charges-in-russia", "title": "American journalist Evan Gershkovich to stand trial on espionage charges in Russia", "body": "Russian prosecutors announced on Thursday that they have finalized an indictment against jailed American journalist Evan Gershkovich, and said he will stand trial on espionage charges in the Russian city of Yekaterinburg, where he was arrested more than a year ago.\n\nGershkovich, 32, was arrested while on a reporting trip for The Wall Street Journal in late March 2023 and is accused of spying for the United States. Gershkovich has vehemently denied the allegations against him -- as has the Journal -- and President Biden has called his detention \"totally illegal.\" The U.S. government has designated Gershkovich \"wrongfully detained,\" meaning the government effectively considers him a political prisoner.\n\nRussian authorities allege that Gershkovich used covert methods to gather information about the Uralvagonzavod factory outside the Ural mountain town of Yekaterinburg -- a facility that has been sanctioned by the West and plays a significant role building tanks and other weapons for Russia in its war against Ukraine.\n\nIn a statement posted to Telegram, Russia's Prosecutor General's office alleged that Gershkovich had \"collected secret information\" under \"instructions from the CIA.\" But prosecutors have not publicly presented any information or evidence to support their claims, and at the time of his arrest, Gershkovich had been accredited to work in Russia by the country's foreign ministry.\n\nProsecutors did not say when the proceedings against Gershkovich would begin, but once they do, he faces the prospect of a trial behind closed doors given that Russian officials say the case involves classified information. If found guilty, he could serve as much as 20 years in prison.\n\nGershkovich is currently being held in pretrial detention at Lefortovo prison in Moscow, where according to the Journal he has been {"uri": "8176187910", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-13", "time": "14:12:41", "dateTime": "2024-06-13T14:12:41Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-13T14:11:45Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8392156958580017, "url": "https://www.thestar.com/news/world/europe/u-s-reporter-evan-gershkovich-jailed-in-russia-on-espionage-charges-to-stand-trial-officials/article_9ea9f3c4-1f04-5b0b-b8d9-1441b7adf050.html", "title": "U.S. reporter Evan Gershkovich, jailed in Russia on espionage charges, to stand trial, officials say", "body": "MOSCOW (AP) -- U.S. journalist Evan Gershkovich, who has been jailed for over a year in Russia on espionage charges, will stand trial in the Ural Mountains city of Yekaterinburg, authorities said Thursday.\n\nAn indictment of the Wall Street Journal reporter has been finalized and his case was filed to the Sverdlovsky Regional Court in the city about 1,400 kilometers (870 miles) east of Moscow, according to Russia's Prosecutor General's office.\n\n\u00d7\n\nAlready a Subscriber? Sign in You are logged in Switch accounts\n\nGershkovich is accused of \"gathering secret information\" for the CIA about Uralvagonzavod, a facility in the Sverdlovsk region that produces and repairs military equipment, the Prosecutor General's office said in a statement, revealing for the first time the details of the accusations against him.\n\nARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW ARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW\n\nThe officials didn't provide any evidence to back up the accusations. There was no word on when the trial would begin.\n\nGershkovich was detained while on a reporting trip to Yekaterinburg in March 2023 and accused of spying for the United States. The reporter, his employer and the U.S. government denied the allegations, and Washington designated him as wrongfully detained.\n\nThe Federal Security Service, or FSB, alleged at the time he was acting on U.S. orders to collect state secrets but also provided no evidence.\n\nPresident Vladimir Putin has said he believed a deal could be reached to free Gershkovich, hinting he would be open to swapping him for a Russian national imprisoned in Germany, which appeared to be Vadim Krasikov. He was serving a life sentence for the 2019 killing in Berlin of a Georgian citizen of Chechen descent.\n\nAsked last week by The Associated Press about Gershkovich, Putin said the U.S. is \"taking energetic steps\" to secure his release. He said any such releases \"aren't decided via mass media\" but through a \"discreet, calm and professional approach.\"\n\nARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW ARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW\n\n\"And they certainly should be decided only on the basis of reciprocity,\" he added in an allusion to a potential prisoner swap.\n\nGershkovich faces up to 20 years in prison if convicted.\n\nHe was the first U.S. journalist taken into custody on espionage charges since Nicholas Daniloff in 1986 at the height of the Cold War. Gershkovich's arrest shocked foreign journalists in Russia, even though the country had enacted increasingly repressive laws on freedom of speech after sending troops into Ukraine.\n\nThe son of Soviet emigres who settled in New Jersey, Gershkovich was fluent in Russian and moved to the country in 2017 to work for The Moscow Times newspaper before being hired by the Journal in 2022.\n\nSince his arrest, Gershkovich has been held at Moscow's Lefortovo Prison, a notorious czarist-era prison used during Josef Stalin's purges, when executions were carried out in its basement.\n\nThe Biden administration has sought to negotiate his release, but Russia's Foreign Ministry said it would consider a prisoner swap only after a verdict in his trial.\n\nARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW ARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW\n\nU.S. Ambassador Lynne Tracy, who regularly visited Gershkovich in prison and attended his court hearings, has called the charges against him \"fiction\" and said that Russia is \"using American citizens as pawns to achieve political ends.\"\n\nSince sending troops to Ukraine, Russian authorities have detained several U.S. nationals and other Westerners, seemingly bolstering that {"uri": "8176146478", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-13", "time": "13:46:59", "dateTime": "2024-06-13T13:46:59Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-13T13:46:17Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8352941274642944, "url": "https://www.news4jax.com/news/world/2024/06/13/us-reporter-evan-gershkovich-jailed-in-russia-on-espionage-charges-to-stand-trial-officials-say/", "title": "US reporter Evan Gershkovich, jailed in Russia on espionage charges, to stand trial, officials say", "body": "MOSCOW - U.S. journalist Evan Gershkovich, who has been jailed for over a year in Russia on espionage charges, will stand trial in the Ural Mountains city of Yekaterinburg, authorities said Thursday.\n\nAn indictment of the Wall Street Journal reporter has been finalized and his case was filed to the Sverdlovsky Regional Court in the city about 1,400 kilometers (870 miles) east of Moscow, according to Russia's Prosecutor General's office.\n\nRecommended Videos\n\nGershkovich is accused of \"gathering secret information\" for the CIA about Uralvagonzavod, a facility in the Sverdlovsk region that produces and repairs military equipment, the Prosecutor General's office said in a statement, revealing for the first time the details of the accusations against him.\n\nThe officials didn't provide any evidence to back up the accusations. There was no word on when the trial would begin.\n\nGershkovich was detained while on a reporting trip to Yekaterinburg in March 2023 and accused of spying for the United States. The reporter, his employer and the U.S. government denied the allegations, and Washington designated him as wrongfully detained.\n\nThe Federal Security Service, or FSB, alleged at the time he was acting on U.S. orders to collect state secrets but also provided no evidence.\n\nPresident Vladimir Putin has said he believed a deal could be reached to free Gershkovich, hinting he would be open to swapping him for a Russian national imprisoned in Germany, which appeared to be Vadim Krasikov. He was serving a life sentence for the 2019 killing in Berlin of a Georgian citizen of Chechen descent.\n\nAsked last week by The Associated Press about Gershkovich, Putin said the U.S. is \"taking energetic steps\" to secure his release. He said any such releases \"aren't decided via mass media\" but through a \"discreet, calm and professional approach.\"\n\n\"And they certainly should be decided only on the basis of reciprocity,\" he added in an allusion to a potential prisoner swap.\n\nGershkovich faces up to 20 years in prison if convicted.\n\nHe was the first U.S. journalist taken into custody on espionage charges since Nicholas Daniloff in 1986 at the height of the Cold War. Gershkovich's arrest shocked foreign journalists in Russia, even though the country had enacted increasingly repressive laws on freedom of speech after sending troops into Ukraine.\n\nThe son of Soviet emigres who settled in New Jersey, Gershkovich was fluent in Russian and moved to the country in 2017 to work for The Moscow Times newspaper before being hired by the Journal in 2022.\n\nSince his arrest, Gershkovich has been held at Moscow's Lefortovo Prison, a notorious czarist-era prison used during Josef Stalin's purges, when executions were carried out in its basement.\n\nThe Biden administration has sought to negotiate his release, but Russia's Foreign Ministry said it would consider a prisoner swap only after a verdict in his trial.\n\nU.S. Ambassador Lynne Tracy, who regularly visited Gershkovich in prison and attended his court hearings, has called the charges against him \"fiction\" and said that Russia is \"using American citizens as pawns to achieve political ends.\"\n\nSince sending troops to Ukraine, Russian authorities have detained several U.S. nationals and other Westerners, seemingly bolstering that idea.", "source": {"uri": "news4jax.com", Russia", "body": "A SHAM trial has been set for falsely jailed reporter Evan Gershkovich who has spent 442 days behind bars in Russia on bogus charges of espionage.\n\nThe innocent American, 32, has been wrongly accused by Vladimir Putin's crooks of spying for the CIA.\n\nGershkovich will stand trial in the Ural Mountains city of Yekaterinburg, 870 miles east of Moscow, authorities announced today.\n\nThe Wall Street Journal reporter is accused of gathering \"secret information\" for the CIA about Uralvagonzavod, a military facility in the Sverdlovsk region.\n\nIt is the first time authorities have announced the details of the accusations against Gershkovich.\n\nThere was no word on when the trial would begin.\n\nGershkovich was detained by the Federal Security Service (FSB) on March 29, 2023, while on a reporting trip to Yekaterinburg.\n\nPutin's spy service alleged that the reporter, acting on the instructions of the US, collected secret information about a Russian military-industrial complex.\n\nBut Russian officials have not provided any evidence to back up their false claims.\n\nBoth Gershkovich and the Journal vehemently deny the allegations, while Washington declares him wrongfully detained.\n\nThe US citizen has repeatedly launched appeals to secure his freedom - all have so far been rejected.\n\nHe is the first Western reporter to be jailed on espionage charges in Russia since the Soviet era, and he faces a prison term of up to 20 years if convicted.\n\nSince his arrest, Gershkovich has been held at Moscow's notorious Lefortovo Prison, the Soviet-era's most prominent prison used during Josef Stalin's purges, when executions were carried out in its basement.\n\nPutin claimed in February he would like to see Gershkovich released as Vadim Krasikov.\n\nHe was serving a life sentence for the 2019 killing in Berlin of a Georgian citizen of Chechen descent.\n\nThe Biden administration has sought to negotiate his release, but Russia's Foreign Ministry said it would consider a prisoner swap only after a verdict in his trial.\n\nUS Ambassador Lynne Tracy, who regularly visited Gershkovich in prison and attended his court hearings, {"uri": "8176380361", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-13", "time": "16:20:45", "dateTime": "2024-06-13T16:20:45Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-13T16:20:08Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8352941274642944, "url": "https://www.npr.org/2024/06/13/nx-s1-5004609/evan-gershkovich-wall-street-journal-espionage-charges-russia-trial", "title": "American journalist Evan Gershkovich to stand trial on espionage charges in Russia", "body": "U.S. journalist Evan Gershkovich stands inside a defendants' cage during a pretrial detention hearing at the Moscow City Court in Moscow on Sept. 19, 2023. Gershkovich was detained during a reporting trip in Russia in March 2023 and accused of spying -- charges that he, the U.S. government and his employer, The Wall Street Journal, vehemently deny. Natalia Kolesnikova/AFP via Getty Images\n\n/AFP hide caption\n\nRussian prosecutors announced on Thursday that they have finalized an indictment against jailed American journalist Evan Gershkovich, and said he will stand trial on espionage charges in the Russian city of Yekaterinburg, where he was arrested more than a year ago.\n\nGershkovich, 32, was arrested while on a reporting trip for The Wall Street Journal in late March 2023 and is accused of spying for the United States. Gershkovich has vehemently denied the allegations against him -- as has the Journal -- and President Biden has called his detention \"totally illegal.\" The U.S. government has designated Gershkovich \"wrongfully detained,\" meaning the government effectively considers him a political prisoner.\n\nRussian authorities allege that Gershkovich used covert methods to gather information about the Uralvagonzavod factory outside the Ural mountain town of Yekaterinburg -- a facility that has been sanctioned by the West and plays a significant role building tanks and other weapons for Russia in its war against Ukraine.\n\nIn a statement posted to Telegram, Russia's Prosecutor General's office alleged that Gershkovich had \"collected secret information\" under \"instructions from the CIA.\" But prosecutors have not publicly presented any information or evidence to support their claims, and at the time of his arrest, Gershkovich had been accredited to work in Russia by the country's foreign ministry.\n\nProsecutors did not say when the proceedings against Gershkovich would begin, but once they do, he faces the prospect of a trial behind closed doors given that Russian officials say the case involves classified information. If found guilty, he could serve as much as 20 years in prison.\n\nGershkovich is currently being held in pretrial detention at Lefortovo prison in Moscow, where according to the Journal he has been {"uri": "8176154859", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-13", "time": "13:51:34", "dateTime": "2024-06-13T13:51:34Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-13T13:51:01Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8352941274642944, "url": "https://torontosun.com/news/world/u-s-reporter-evan-gershkovich-jailed-in-russia-on-espionage-charges-to-stand-trial-officials-say", "title": "U.S. reporter Evan Gershkovich, jailed in Russia on espionage charges, to stand trial, officials say", "body": "Try refreshing your browser, or\n\ntap here to see other videos from our team.\n\nRussia's Prosecutor General's office said an indictment of Gershkovich has been finalized and his case was filed to the Sverdlovsky Regional Court in the city in the Ural Mountains.\n\nGershkovich is accused of \"gathering secret information\" about a facility in the Sverdlovsk region that produced and repaired military equipment, the Prosecutor General's office said in a statement, revealing for the first time the details of the accusations against the jailed reporter. Gershkovich has been charged with espionage.\n\nThe officials didn't provide any evidence to back up the accusations.\n\nGershkovich was detained while on a reporting trip to Yekaterinburg in March 2023 and accused of spying for the U.S. The Federal Security Service, or FSB, alleged at the time he was acting on U.S. orders to collect state secrets but also provided no evidence. Washington designated him as wrongfully detained.\n\nHe was the first U.S. journalist taken into custody on espionage charges since Nicholas Daniloff in 1986 at the height of the Cold War. Gershkovich's arrest shocked foreign journalists in Russia, even though the country had enacted increasingly repressive laws on freedom of speech after sending troops into Ukraine.", "source": {"uri": {"uri": "8176715844", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-13", "time": "21:15:11", "dateTime": "2024-06-13T21:15:11Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-13T21:14:24Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8313725590705872, "url": "https://www.wfae.org/2024-06-13/american-journalist-evan-gershkovich-to-stand-trial-on-espionage-charges-in-russia", "title": "American journalist Evan Gershkovich to stand trial on espionage charges in Russia", "body": "Russian prosecutors announced on Thursday that they have finalized an indictment against jailed American journalist Evan Gershkovich, and said he will stand trial on espionage charges in the Russian city of Yekaterinburg, where he was arrested more than a year ago.\n\nGershkovich, 32, was arrested while on a reporting trip for The Wall Street Journal in late March 2023 and is accused of spying for the United States. Gershkovich has vehemently denied the allegations against him -- as has the Journal -- and President Biden has called his detention \"totally illegal.\" The U.S. government has designated Gershkovich \"wrongfully detained,\" meaning the government effectively considers him a political prisoner.\n\nRussian authorities allege that Gershkovich used covert methods to gather information about the Uralvagonzavod factory outside the Ural mountain town of Yekaterinburg -- a facility that has been sanctioned by the West and plays a significant role building tanks and other weapons for Russia in its war against Ukraine.\n\nIn a statement posted to Telegram, Russia's Prosecutor General's office alleged that Gershkovich had \"collected secret information\" under \"instructions from the CIA.\" But prosecutors have not publicly presented any information or evidence to support their claims, and at the time of his arrest, Gershkovich had been accredited to work in Russia by the country's foreign ministry.\n\nThe top leadership of The Wall Street Journal responded to the announcement by Russian prosecutors by calling the allegations against Gershkovich \"an assault on free press.\"\n\n\"Evan Gershkovich is facing a false and baseless charge. Russia's latest move toward a sham trial is, while expected, deeply disappointing and still no less outrageous,\" said the paper's publisher, Almar Latour, and its editor-in-chief, Emma Tucker, in a statement. \"The Russian regime's smearing of Evan is repugnant, disgusting and based on calculated and transparent lies. Journalism is not a crime,\" they added.\n\nThe U.S. State Department also denounced the charges, with spokesman Matthew Miller telling reporters that Gershkovich \"should be released immediately.\"\n\n\"There is absolutely zero credibility to those charges,\" Miller said. \"We have been clear from the start that Evan has done nothing wrong. He should have never been arrested in the first place.\"\n\nProsecutors did not say when the proceedings against Gershkovich would begin, but once they do, he faces the prospect of a trial behind closed doors given that Russian officials say the case involves classified information. If found guilty, he could serve as much as 20 years in prison.\n\nGershkovich is currently being held in pretrial detention at Lefortovo prison in Moscow, where according to the Journal he has been confined 23 hours a day to his cell, leaving only for meetings with his attorneys or U.S. embassy officials, and for occasional court appearances.\n\nWith his arrest last year, Gershkovich became the first American journalist to be detained by Russia on espionage charges since KGB operatives took the reporter Nicholas Daniloff into custody in 1986. At the time, the effort to free Daniloff meant having to navigate Cold War tensions between Washington and Moscow. Now, the effort to negotiate Gershkovich's freedom has been complicated by deepening friction between the U.S. and Russia in the aftermath Russia's invasion of Ukraine.\n\nGershkovich is not the only American currently being held in Russia. Paul Whelan, a former U.S. Marine, is currently serving a 16-year sentence after being convicted of similar charges, and Alsu Kurmasheva, a Russian American journalist with the U.S.-government funded Radio Free Europe/Radio Liberty news service, is being detained on charges of failing to register as a \"foreign agent.\"\n\nIn recent years, the U.S. has agreed to several notable prisoner swaps with Russia. In 2022, the U.S. secured the release of the U.S. Marine veteran Trevor Reed in exchange for Konstantin Yaroshenko, a pilot sentenced to more than 20 years in prison for conspiring to import more than $100 million of cocaine into the country.\n\nLater that year, the U.S. released the convicted Russian arms-trafficker Viktor Boutin exchange for the WNBA star Brittney Griner. While families of detained Americans have cheered these exchanges, critics have said they incentivize Russia to take more Westerners prisoner in order to use as future bargaining chips.\n\nAddressing lawmakers on Capitol Hill on Thursday, the special presidential envoy for hostage affairs, Roger Carstens, told House lawmakers the announcement by Russian prosecutors was not unexpected.\n\n\"I think we were all hopeful that we would be able to broker a deal with the Russians before this happened. But it doesn't stop or slow us down. We can keep continuing to pursue not only Evan's freedom, but also Paul Whelan's freedom as well,\" Carstens said in testimony to the House Foreign Affairs Committee.", "source": {"uri": "wfae.org", {"uri": "8176597176", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-13", "time": "19:19:55", "dateTime": "2024-06-13T19:19:55Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-13T19:17:58Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8313725590705872, "url": "https://www.yahoo.com/news/evan-gershkovich-stand-trial-russia-155926488.html", "title": "Evan Gershkovich to stand trial in Russia on espionage charges", "body": "American journalist Evan Gershkovich will stand trial in Russia on charges of spying for the CIA, prosecutors announced Thursday.\n\nGershkovich, a Wall Street Journal reporter, was arrested in March 2023 on what many in the West consider trumped-up charges by Russian President Vladimir Putin's repressive government.\n\nPresident Joe Biden has repeatedly called on Putin to release Gershkovich, 32, who was arrested while on a reporting trip in the Ural Mountains city of Yekaterinburg. Gershkovich, his employer and the U.S. government have all vehemently denied the allegations.\n\nAfter more than a year in pretrial detention, the Russian Prosecutor General's Office said Thursday that Gershkovich's case would be sent to the Sverdlovsk Regional Court, in the city where he was arrested, for trial at an unspecified date.\n\nThe prosecutor's office said that Gershkovich's indictment on espionage charges had been finalized following an investigation by Russia's Federal Security Service, or FSB.\n\nIt said he had \"acted on instructions from the CIA\" and \"collected secret information\" about the manufacturer Uralvagonzavod, a facility in the region that produces and repairs military equipment. It added that \"illegal actions were carried out by Gershkovich in compliance with careful measures of secrecy.\"\n\nRussian authorities have presented no evidence to support their accusations, which were revealed for the first time in Thursday's statement.\n\nGershkovich faces up to 20 years in prison if convicted.\n\nIn a joint statement, Dow Jones CEO and Wall Street Journal Publisher Almar Latour and Wall Street Journal Editor-in-Chief Emma Tucker said \"we had hoped to avoid this moment.\"\n\n\"Evan Gershkovich is facing a false and baseless charge,\" it said. \"Russia's latest move toward a sham trial is, while expected, deeply disappointing and still no less outrageous. Evan has spent 441 days wrongfully detained in a Russian prison for simply doing his job.\"\n\nGershkovich's arrest has been condemned by journalists and government officials across the West, who see it as emblematic of the war Putin has waged against freedom of speech both in Russia and abroad.\n\nThe U.S. has designated Gershkovich as wrongfully detained, with Ambassador Lynne Tracy saying at a hearing in March that \"the accusations against Evan are categorically untrue.\"\n\nBut Putin has signaled he believes a deal could be struck to free Gershkovich.\n\nA possible exchange had been in the works that could have resulted in the release of Gershkovich, former Marine Paul Whelan, and Russian opposition leader Alexei Navalny, sources told NBC News in February.\n\nThe swap was not thought to be imminent when the death of Navalny in an Arctic penal colony was announced on Feb. 16., five sources told NBC News.\n\nGershkovich has been kept in Moscow's notorious Lefortovo Prison, which is known for its harsh conditions. His multiple appeals have been rejected in court, and a previous announcement said that his pretrial detention had been extended until at least June 30.\n\nDuring these court appearances, Gershkovich often smiles and appears in good spirits. But his detention has weighed on his family.\n\n\"It has been hard,\" his father, Mikhail Gershkovich, told NBC News in March to mark the anniversary of his arrest. \"He spent all four seasons there, he spent his birthday and all the holidays. We want him home as soon as possible.\"\n\nHis parents left the then-Soviet Union for the U.S. during the Cold War. He and his older sister grew up speaking Russian at home, and the family calls him \"Vanya,\" the diminutive for his Russian name, Ivan.\n\nHis interest in Russia motivated his decision to move there in 2017 to work as a journalist.\n\nBut everything changed when Russia invaded Ukraine in Feb. 2022, the family said. Like many other foreign reporters wary of Russia's tightening grip on press freedom, Gershkovich moved abroad, albeit regularly returning for reporting trips.\n\nSince his arrest, another American Russian journalist, Alsu Kurmasheva, has also been detained, along with several other U.S. nationals. The U.S. government has said this is a deliberate strategy by Putin to use them as geopolitical pawns.", "source": {"uri": "yahoo.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Yahoo"}, "authors": [], {"uri": "2024-06-388520925", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-13", "time": "14:46:08", "dateTime": "2024-06-13T14:46:08Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-13T14:37:33Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8313725590705872, "url": "https://www.i24news.tv/en/news/international/artc-russia-indicts-wall-street-journal-reporter-evan-gershkovich", "title": "Russia indicts Wall Street Journal reporter Evan Gershkovich", "body": "Gershkovich, a 32-year-old American son of Jewish immigrants from the Soviet Union, was arrested in March 2023 while on a reporting trip in the city of Yekaterinburg\n\nRussian prosecutors announced on Thursday that they have indicted Wall Street Journal reporter Evan Gershkovich on espionage charges, escalating a case that has drawn international condemnation.\n\nGershkovich, a 32-year-old American son of Jewish immigrants from the Soviet Union, was arrested in March 2023 while on a reporting trip in the city of Yekaterinburg.\n\nThe U.S. government, his employer, and Gershkovich himself vehemently deny the allegations, for which the Russian government has not provided any evidence. The U.S. considers him to be wrongfully detained.\n\nFollowing more than a year in pretrial detention, the Russian Prosecutor General's Office announced that Gershkovich's case would be sent to the Sverdlovsk Regional Court in Yekaterinburg for trial at an unspecified date. The trial is expected to involve a series of secret, closed-door hearings, according to the Wall Street Journal.\n\nThe prosecutor's office stated that the indictment was finalized after an investigation by Russia's Federal Security Service (FSB). They accused Gershkovich of \"acting on instructions from the CIA\" and \"collecting secret information\" about Uralvagonzavod, a manufacturer of military equipment in the region.\n\nThe office claimed that \"illegal actions were carried out by Gershkovich in compliance with careful measures of secrecy.\" No evidence supporting these accusations was presented.\n\nIf convicted, Gershkovich faces up to 20 years in prison. His case has become a rallying point for journalists and government officials worldwide, who see it as emblematic of the broader crackdown on press freedom by Russian President Vladimir Putin.\n\nThe U.S. has designated Gershkovich as wrongfully detained.\n\nIn a March hearing, U.S. Ambassador Lynne Tracy asserted, \"the accusations against Evan are categorically untrue.\" Discussions have suggested a potential deal could be made to secure his release. A proposed exchange, which would have included former Marine Paul Whelan and Russian opposition leader Alexei Navalny, was reportedly in the works.\n\nGershkovich is currently held in Moscow's notorious Lefortovo Prison, known for its harsh conditions. His multiple appeals have been rejected, and his pretrial detention has been extended until at least June 30.\n\nDespite the dire circumstances, Gershkovich often appears in good spirits during court appearances. However, his detention has deeply affected his family.\n\n\"It has been hard,\" his father, Mikhail Gershkovich, told NBC News in March. \"He spent all four seasons there, he spent his birthday and all the holidays. We want him home as soon as possible.\"\n\nGershkovich's parents left the Soviet Union for the U.S. during the Cold War, and he grew up speaking Russian at home. His interest in Russia led him to move there in 2017 to work as a journalist.\n\nThe situation drastically changed after Russia's full-scale invasion of Ukraine in February 2022. Like many foreign reporters, Gershkovich became increasingly wary of Russia's tightening grip on press freedom and moved abroad, although he continued to return for reporting trips.", "source": {"uri": "8176150091", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-13", "time": "13:49:42", "dateTime": "2024-06-13T13:49:42Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-13T13:48:35Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8274509906768799, "url": "https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/europe/evan-gershkovich-ap-russia-moscow-yekaterinburg-b2562072.html", "title": "US reporter Evan Gershkovich, jailed in Russia on espionage charges, to stand trial, officials say", "body": "An indictment of the Wall Street Journal reporter has been finalized and his case was filed to the Sverdlovsky Regional Court in the city about 1,400 kilometers (870 miles) east of Moscow, according to Russia's Prosecutor General's office.\n\nGershkovich is accused of \"gathering secret information\" for the CIA about Uralvagonzavod, a facility in the Sverdlovsk region that produces and repairs military equipment, the Prosecutor General's office said in a statement, revealing for the first time the details of the accusations against him.\n\nThe officials didn't provide any evidence to back up the accusations. There was no word on when the trial would begin.\n\nGershkovich was detained while on a reporting trip to Yekaterinburg in March 2023 and accused of spying for the United States. The reporter, his employer and the U.S. government denied the allegations, and Washington designated him as wrongfully detained.\n\nThe Federal Security Service, or FSB, alleged at the time he was acting on U.S. orders to collect state secrets but also provided no evidence.\n\nPresident Vladimir Putin has said he believed a deal could be reached to free Gershkovich, hinting he would be open to swapping him for a Russian national imprisoned in Germany, which appeared to be Vadim Krasikov. He was serving a life sentence for the 2019 killing in Berlin of a Georgian citizen of Chechen descent.\n\nAsked last week by The Associated Press about Gershkovich, Putin said the U.S. is \"taking energetic steps\" to secure his release. He said any such releases \"aren't decided via mass media\" but through a \"discreet, calm and professional approach.\"\n\n\"And they certainly should be decided only on the basis of reciprocity,\" he added in an allusion to a potential prisoner swap.\n\nGershkovich faces up to 20 years in prison if convicted.\n\nHe was the first U.S. journalist taken into custody on espionage charges since Nicholas Daniloff in 1986 at the height of the Cold War. Gershkovich's arrest shocked foreign journalists in Russia, even though the country had enacted increasingly repressive laws on freedom of speech after sending troops into Ukraine.\n\nThe son of Soviet emigres who settled in New Jersey, Gershkovich was fluent in Russian and moved to the country in 2017 to work for The Moscow Times newspaper before being hired by the Journal in 2022.\n\nSince his arrest, Gershkovich has been held at Moscow's Lefortovo Prison, a notorious czarist-era prison used during Josef Stalin's purges, when executions were carried out in its basement.\n\nThe Biden administration has sought to negotiate his release, but Russia's Foreign Ministry said it would consider a prisoner swap only after a verdict in his trial.\n\nU.S. Ambassador Lynne Tracy, who regularly visited Gershkovich in prison and attended his court hearings, has called the charges against him \"fiction\" and said that Russia is \"using American citizens as pawns to achieve political ends.\"\n\nSince sending troops to Ukraine, Russian authorities have detained several U.S. nationals and other Westerners, seemingly bolstering that idea.", "source": {"uri": "independent.co.uk", {"uri": "2024-06-388775748", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-13", "time": "19:28:51", "dateTime": "2024-06-13T19:28:51Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-13T18:51:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8235294222831726, "url": "https://www.yahoo.com/gma/wall-street-journal-reporter-evan-132700377.html", "title": "Wall Street Journal reporter Evan Gershkovich to stand trial in Russia on espionage charges", "body": "In a setback to Wall Street Journal reporter Evan Gershkovich, the Russian prosecutor's office announced Thursday he will stand trial on espionage charges, officially ending any future pre-detention appeals.\n\n\"The Prosecutor General's Office of the Russian Federation has approved an indictment in the criminal case against US citizen Evan Gershkovich,\" the office said in a statement. \"The criminal case has been sent to the Sverdlovsk Regional Court for consideration on the merits.\"\n\nIt continued, \"The investigation established and documented that the American journalist of The Wall Street Journal, Gershkovich, on the instructions of the CIA in March 2023, collected secret information in the Sverdlovsk region about the activities of the defense enterprise JSC NPK Uralvagonzavod for the production and repair of military equipment.\"\n\nMORE: Biden, top lawmakers denounce Russia's yearlong detention of Evan Gershkovich\n\nGershkovich has denied he was involved in any espionage and the U.S. State Department has declared him to be wrongfully detained.\n\nThe statement Thursday marks the first time prosecutors have publicly accused Gershkovich of working for the CIA, alleging without evidence that he was collecting \"secret information\" on a tank factory in the Sverdlovsk region. Gershkovich, The Wall Street Journal, the U.S. government and Gershkovich's many colleagues all vehemently dispute he was working as a spy and say that he was doing his job as a reporter.\n\nGershkovich was on a reporting trip in Yekaterinburg, the capital of the Sverdlovsk region, when he was arrested in March 2023.\n\nPreviously, prosecutors have alleged Gershkovich was working for a foreign intelligence service without specifying which one.\n\n\"Evan Gershkovich is facing a false and baseless charge,\" Almar Latour, Dow Jones CEO and Wall Street Journal publisher, and Emma Tucker, Wall Street Journal editor in chief, said in a joint statement published in The Wall Street Journal. \"Russia's latest move toward a sham trial is, while expected, deeply disappointing and still no less outrageous.\"\n\nThey added, \"Evan has spent 441 days wrongfully detained in a Russian prison for simply doing his job. Evan is a journalist. The Russian regime's smearing of Evan is repugnant, disgusting and based on calculated and transparent lies. Journalism is not a crime. Evan's case is an assault on free press.\"\n\nMORE: Parents of reporter Evan Gershkovich speak out 1 year into his Russian detainment: Exclusive\n\nIn March, Gershkovich's parents had told ABC News they were optimistic about progress in their son's case.\n\n\"We know that the U.S. government is taking Evan's case very seriously,\" his mother, Ella Milman, told \"Good Morning America\" co-anchor George Stephanopoulos in an exclusive sit-down interview.\n\n\"I think if you let the pessimism in ... the game is over,\" she said. \"And our saying in the family is we're moving forward. Moving forward.\"\n\nRussian President Vladimir Putin made his first comments on Gershkovich's detention in months on June 5.\n\n\"I know that the United States administration is really taking energetic steps for his release. This is true. But such issues are not resolved through the media,\" Putin said. \"They love such a quiet, calm professional approach and dialogue between the intelligence services.\"\n\nHe added, \"You know, you believe that he is innocent, and Russian law enforcement agencies and special services believe that he committed illegal actions, which are called espionage. I will not go into details.\"\n\nGershkovich most recently appeared in court in Moscow for a pretrial hearing on April 23 as part of an appeal against the spying charges. His appeal was denied and he was ordered held through at least June 30.\n\nMORE: WSJ reporter Evan Gershkovich's detention in Russia extended to June 30\n\nThe reporter smiled and gave a thumb's up when asked by ABC News inside the courtroom how he was doing.\n\n\"He has one more appeal that he can make, appealing his detention, but what's most likely going to happen before the 30th of June is Evan will be moved from Lefortovo, where he is currently held in prison, to instead Yekaterinburg, and when he gets out to Yekaterinburg, that's when the trial process most likely will start,\" U.S. Special Envoy for Hostage Affairs Roger Carstens said Thursday during a hearing on Capitol Hill.\n\nCarstens continued: \"I will tell you, if it's anything like what happened to Brittney Griner, Paul Whelan, Trevor Reed, there will be a period when he leaves Lefortovo where we won't have any contact with him. It'll almost be like it's gone dark.\"\n\nThe U.S. has been negotiating the release of both Gershkovich and Paul Whelan since not long after their detentions. Whelan, a former U.S. Marine, was also accused of spying in 2018 and convicted in June 2020. Like Gershkovich, he has been declared wrongfully detained by the U.S. government.\n\n\"We're going to continue to try to pursue his release,\" State Department spokesperson Matt Miller said Thursday of Gershkovich. \"We put a substantial offer on the table to secure the release of Evan and Paul Whelan some months ago, as we said publicly, we're continuing to work to secure their release. It's one of the secretary's and the president's highest priorities.\"\n\nABC News' Shannon K. The journalist has spent more than a year in pre-trial detention. The Russian Prosecutor General's Office said Thursday that Gershkovich would be sent to the Sverdlovsk Regional Court, in the city where he was arrested, for trial at an unspecified date.\n\nThe prosecutor's office said that Gershkovich had been charged with espionage following an investigation by Russia's Federal Security Service, or FSB.\n\nIt said he had \"acted on instructions from the CIA\" and \"collected secret information\" about the mass tank manufacturer UralVagonZavod \"for the production and repair of military equipment.\"\n\nIt added, \"Illegal actions were carried out by Gershkovich in compliance with careful measures of secrecy.\"\n\nRussian authorities have presented no evidence to support their case.\n\nGershkovich's case has become a campaigning issue for journalists and government officials throughout the West, who see it emblematic of the war Putin has waged against freedom of speech both domestic and foreign.\n\nHis employer and U.S. officials have repeatedly rejected the charges as baseless. "sim": 0.8196078538894653, "url": "https://www.wandsworthguardian.co.uk/news/national/24386621.us-reporter-evan-gershkovich-held-russia-espionage-charges-face-trial/", "title": "US reporter Evan Gershkovich, held in Russia on espionage charges, to face trial", "body": "An indictment of The Wall Street Journal reporter has been finalised and his case was filed to the Sverdlovsky Regional Court in the city about 1,400 kilometres (870 miles) east of Moscow, according to Russia's Prosecutor General's Office.\n\nGershkovich, 32, is accused of \"gathering secret information\" on orders from the CIA about Uralvagonzavod, a facility in the Sverdlovsk region that produces and repairs military equipment, the Prosecutor General's Office said in a statement, revealing for the first time the details of the accusations against him.\n\nThe officials did not provide any evidence to back up the accusations.\n\nThere was no word on when the trial would begin.\n\nThe Biden administration has sought to negotiate his release, but Russia's Foreign Ministry said Moscow would consider a prisoner swap only after a verdict in his trial.\n\nGershkovich was detained while on a reporting trip to Yekaterinburg in March 2023 and accused of spying for the United States.\n\nThe reporter, his employer and the US government denied the allegations, and Washington designated him as wrongfully detained.\n\nThe Federal Security Service (FSB) alleged at the time he was acting on US orders to collect state secrets but also provided no evidence.\n\n\"Russia's latest move toward a sham trial is, while expected, deeply disappointing and still no less outrageous,\" according to a statement by Almar Latour, Dow Jones chief executive and publisher of the Journal, and Emma Tucker, the Journal's editor in chief.\n\nThey added that the charges against Gershkovich were \"false and baseless\".\n\n\"The Russian regime's smearing of Evan is repugnant, disgusting and based on calculated and transparent lies. Journalism is not a crime. Evan's case is an assault on free press,\" the statement said.\n\n\"We had hoped to avoid this moment and now expect the US government to redouble efforts to get Evan released.\"\n\nUralvagonzavod, a state tank and railroad car factory in the city of Nizhny Tagil about 100 kilometres (60 miles) north of Yekaterinburg, became known in 2011-12 as a bedrock of support for President Vladimir Putin.\n\nThe plant foreman appeared on Mr Putin's annual phone-in programme in December 2011 and denounced mass protests occurring in Moscow at the time as a threat to \"stability\", proposing that he and his colleagues travel to the capital to help suppress the unrest.\n\nA week later, Mr Putin appointed the plant foreman to be his envoy in the region.\n\nMr Putin has said he believed a deal could be reached to free Gershkovich, hinting he would be open to swapping him for a Russian national imprisoned in Germany, which appeared to be Vadim Krasikov.\n\nHe was serving a life sentence for the 2019 killing in Berlin of a Georgian citizen of Chechen descent.\n\nAsked last week by The Associated Press about Gershkovich, Mr Putin said the US is \"taking energetic steps\" to secure his release.\n\nHe told international news agencies in St Petersburg that any such releases \"aren't decided via mass media\" but through a \"discreet, calm and professional approach\".\n\n\"And they certainly should be decided only on the basis of reciprocity,\" he added in an allusion to a potential prisoner swap.\n\nGershkovich faces up to 20 years in prison if convicted.\n\nHe was the first US journalist taken into custody on espionage charges since Nicholas Daniloff in 1986 at the height of the Cold War.\n\nGershkovich's arrest shocked foreign journalists in Russia, even though the country had enacted increasingly repressive laws on freedom of speech after sending troops into Ukraine.\n\nThe son of Soviet emigres who settled in New Jersey, Gershkovich was fluent in Russian and moved to the country in 2017 to work for The Moscow Times newspaper before being hired by the Journal in 2022.\n\nSince his arrest, Gershkovich has been held at Moscow's Lefortovo Prison, a notorious tsarist-era prison used during Joseph Stalin's purges, when executions were carried out in its basement.\n\nUS ambassador Lynne Tracy, who regularly visited Gershkovich in prison and attended his court hearings, has called the charges against him \"fiction\" and said that Russia is \"using American citizens as pawns to achieve political ends\".\n\nSince sending troops to Ukraine, Russian authorities have detained several US nationals and other Westerners, seemingly bolstering that idea.", "source": {"uri": "wandsworthguardian.co.uk", "dataType": "news", "title": "Wandsworth Times"}, Gershkovich, The Wall Street Journal, the U.S. government and Gershkovich's many colleagues all vehemently dispute he was working as a spy and say that he was doing his job as a reporter.\n\nRELATED: Evan Gershkovich's parents speak out nearly 1 year after American journalist detained by Russia\n\nGershkovich was on a reporting trip in Yekaterinburg, the capital of the Sverdlovsk region, when he was arrested in March 2023.\n\nPreviously, prosecutors have alleged Gershkovich was working for a foreign intelligence service without specifying which one.\n\nIn March, Gershkovich's parents had told ABC News they were optimistic about progress in their son's case.\n\n\"We know that the U.S. government is taking Evan's case very seriously,\" his mother, Ella Milman, told \"Good Morning America\" co-anchor George Stephanopoulos in an exclusive sit-down interview.\n\n\"I think if you let the pessimism in ... the game is over,\" she said. \"And our saying in the family is we're moving forward. Moving forward.\"\n\nRussian President Vladimir Putin made his first comments on Gershkovich's detention in months on June 5.\n\nRELATED: Putin hints at possible prisoner swap for detained NJ native, WSJ journalist Evan Gershkovich\n\n\"I know that the United States administration is really taking energetic steps for his release. I will not go into details.\"\n\nGershkovich most recently appeared in court in Moscow for a pretrial hearing on April 23 as part of an appeal against the spying charges. {"uri": "8176651510", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-13", "time": "20:15:52", "dateTime": "2024-06-13T20:15:52Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-13T20:10:39Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.800000011920929, "url": "https://exbulletin.com/world/2742988/", "title": "Evan Gershkovich, Wall Street Journal reporter, accused of spying for the CIAExBulletin - ExBulletin", "body": "Natalia Kolesnikova/AFP via Getty Images\n\n/AFP via Getty Images\n\nRussian prosecutors announced Thursday that they have finalized an indictment against jailed American journalist Evan Gershkovich and said he will stand trial on espionage charges in the Russian city of Yekaterinburg, where he was arrested more than a year ago.\n\nGershkovich, 32, was arrested while on a reporting trip for The Wall Street Journal LATER March 2023 and is accused of spying for the United States. Gershkovich has vehemently denied the allegations against him, as has he diary and President Biden has called his ban \"totally illegalThe US government has designated Gershkovich \"wrongfully arrested,\" meaning the government considers him a political prisoner.\n\nRussian authorities allege that Gershkovich used covert methods to gather information about the Uralvagonzavod plant outside the Ural mountain city of Yekaterinburg, a facility that has been sanctioned by the west and plays an important role in building tanks and other weapons for Russia in its war against Ukraine.\n\nIn a statement posted on Telegram, Russia's Prosecutor General's office claimed that Gershkovich had \"collected secret information\" under \"instructions from the CIA\". But prosecutors have not publicly presented any information or evidence to support their claims, and at the time of his arrest, Gershkovich was accredited to work in Russia by the country's foreign ministry.\n\nThe senior leadership of of Wall Street Journal responded to the Russian prosecutors' announcement by calling the charges against Gershkovich \"an attack on the free press.\"\n\n\"Evan Gershkovich is facing a false and baseless charge. Russia's latest move toward a sham trial is, while expected, deeply disappointing and no less scandalous,\" said the paper's publisher, Almar Latour, and editor-in-chief of her, Emma Tucker. , in a statement. \"Evan's announcement from the Russian regime is despicable, despicable and based on calculated and transparent lies. Journalism is not a crime,\" they added.\n\nThe US State Department also denounced the charges, with spokesman Matthew Miller telling reporters that Gershkovich \"must be released immediately\".\n\n\"There is absolutely zero credibility to these allegations,\" Miller said. \"We've been clear from the beginning that Evan did nothing wrong. He should never have been arrested in the first place.\"\n\nProsecutors did not say when they would begin proceedings against Gershkovich, but once they do, he faces the possibility of a trial behind closed doors, as Russian officials say the case involves classified information. If convicted, he could serve up to 20 years in prison.\n\nGershkovich is currently being held in custody at Lefortovo prison in Moscow, where according to diary he has been locked up 23 hours a day in his cell, leaving only for meetings with his lawyers or US embassy officials and for occasional court appearances.\n\nWith his arrest last year, Gershkovich became the first American journalist to be arrested by Russia on espionage charges since KGB operatives took reporter Nicholas Daniloff into custody in 1986. At the time, the effort to free Daniloff it meant the need to navigate Cold War tensions between Washington and Moscow. Now, the effort to negotiate Gershkovich's freedom has been complicated by deepening friction between the US and Russia over Russia's invasion of Ukraine.\n\nGershkovich is not the only American currently being held in Russia. Paul Whelan, a former US Marine, is currently serving a 16-year sentence after being convicted ofsimilar charges, and Alsu Kurmasheva, a Russian-American journalist with the US government-funded Radio Free Europe/Radio Liberty news service, has been arrested on charges of failing to register as a \"foreign agent\".\n\nIn recent years, the US has agreed to several notable prisoner exchanges with Russia. In 2022, the US secured the release of US Navy veteran Trevor Reed in exchange for Konstantin Yaroshenko, a pilot sentenced to more than 20 years in prison for conspiring to import more than $100 million worth of cocaine into the country.\n\nLater that year, the US released convicted Russian arms trafficker Viktor Boutin in exchange for WNBA star Brittney Griner. While the families of the detained Americans have cheered the swaps, critics have said they encourage Russia to take more imprisoned Westerners to use as bargaining chips in the future.\n\nAddressing lawmakers on Capitol Hill Thursday, the president's special envoy for hostage issues, Roger Carstens, told House lawmakers that the announcement by Russian prosecutors was not unexpected.\n\n\"I think we were all hoping that we would be able to broker a deal with the Russians before this happened. But that doesn't stop us or slow us down. We can continue to pursue not only Evan's freedom, but the freedom and Paul Whelan, too,\" Carstens said in testimony to the House Foreign Affairs Committee.\n\nRussian President Vladimir Putin has said he believes a deal could be reached to release Gershkovich, but in comments to international news agencies in St Petersburg last week, he suggested it would mean another prisoner swap. Negotiations \"are not decided through mass media,\" he said, but \"only on the basis of reciprocity.\"", "source": {"uri": "exbulletin.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "ExBulletin"}, "authors": [], A start date is yet to be announced.\n\nMr Gershkovich faces up to 20 years in prison if convicted.\n\nUS government responds\n\nUS State Department spokesman Matthew Miller has said there is \"absolutely zero credibility to those charges\" and vowed the US government will continue working to bring Mr Gershkovich home.\n\n\"Evan has done nothing wrong. He should never have been arrested in the first place. Journalism is not a crime,\" he said.\n\n\"The charges against him are false. And the Russian government knows that they're false. He should be released immediately.\"\n\nMore from Sky News:\n\nWhy is worldwide migration higher than ever?\n\nViolence erupts in Argentina\n\nThe Biden administration has been trying to negotiate Mr reporting trip to Yekaterinburg, which is roughly 1,400km east of Moscow, in March 2023.\n\nThe reporter, The Wall Street Journal and the US government have repeatedly denied Russia's accusations, while Washington has designated him as wrongfully detained.\n\nSince his arrest, Mr Gershkovich has been held at Moscow's Lefortovo Prison - a notorious jail used during Joseph Stalin's purges, when
